It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that 11 other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nHe was clearing a building when a booby trap exploded, killed him and injured the other 11 members of the team, said Utah Gov. Gary Herbert.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nThe family of the slain solider identified him as Aaron Butler, 27, of Monticello, Utah. His father Randy Butler said in a statement he was a champion high school wrestler who became a Green Beret after graduating from the U.S. Army Special Forces qualification course with honors in 2016.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\n___", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.9058823585510254, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9774179", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "ksnt.com", "title": "KSNT News", "id": "2852"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://lintvksnt.files.wordpress.com/2017/08/preview-v001560.jpg?w=640", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://ksnt.com/2017/08/17/us-soldier-killed-in-battle-with-is-in-afghanistan/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:45:00", "title": "US soldier killed in battle with IS in Afghanistan", "uri": "711106727", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:45:00Z", "time": "20:45:00", "body": "KABUL, Afghanistan (AP) -- An American soldier was killed and several others were wounded in a battle with Islamic State militants in eastern Afghanistan, the U.S. military said.\n\nThe military said in a statement that several Afghan forces were also wounded in the fighting on Wednesday in the Achin district of the Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that 11 other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nHe was clearing a building when a booby trap exploded, killed him and injured the other 11 members of the team, said Utah Gov. Gary Herbert.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nThe family of the slain solider identified him as Aaron Butler, 27, of Monticello, Utah. His father Randy Butler said in a statement he was a champion high school wrestler who became a Green Beret after graduating from the U.S. Army Special Forces qualification course with honors in 2016.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.9019607901573181, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9852232", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "arkansasonline.com", "title": "ArkansasOnline", "id": "766"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://media.arkansasonline.com/img/photos/2017/08/18/149689247_149686082-8ca7aef9402747c78651e3125bfc961a_t600.jpg?4326734cdb8e39baa3579048ef63ad7b451e7676", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2017/aug/18/utah-soldier-dies-in-afghanistan-201708/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:31:00", "title": "Utah soldier dies in Afghanistan", "uri": "711334275", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T08:31:00Z", "time": "08:31:00", "body": "KABUL, Afghanistan -- A U.S. soldier was killed and several others were wounded in a battle with Islamic State militants in eastern Afghanistan, the U.S. military said.\n\nThe military said in a statement that several Afghan soldiers also were wounded in the fighting Wednesday in the Achin district of Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks Wednesday killed three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that 11 other guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nThe soldier was clearing a building when a booby trap exploded, killing him and injuring the others, Utah Gov. Gary Herbert said.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated.\n\nThe family of the slain soldier identified him as Aaron Butler, 27, of Monticello, Utah. His father, Randy Butler, said in a statement that he was a champion high school wrestler who became a Green Beret after graduating from the U.S. Army Special Forces Qualification Course with honors in 2016.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more-established Taliban.\n\nThe Islamic State affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen. A police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nThe battle continued into Thursday morning, he said. Along with the eight killed, three other policemen were wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters also were killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their call for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more troops to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up over broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\nDefense Secretary James Mattis said Thursday that the Trump administration has almost reached a decision on a new approach for the war in Afghanistan.\n\nHe gave no hint of what the strategy would look like. But in remarks at the State Department, Mattis told reporters that Trump will confer with his national security team today at the Camp David presidential retreat in Maryland, and said the talks \"will move this toward a decision.\"\n\n\"We are coming very close to a decision, and I anticipate it in the very near future,\" he added.\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Mirwais Khan, Lindsay Whitehurst and Robert Burns of The Associated Press.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100, "id": 161, "label": Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. {"sim": 0.8941176533699036, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9717273", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://i.dailymail.co.uk/i/pix/2017/08/17/15/4345922D00000578-0-image-a-57_1502981539195.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4799732/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:07:00", "title": "Utah National Guard soldier is killed fighting ISIS in Afghanistan", "uri": "710953451", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T15:07:00Z", "time": "15:07:00", "body": "An American soldier was killed and several others were wounded in a battle with Islamic State militants in eastern Afghanistan, the US military said.\n\nThe military said in a statement that several Afghan forces were also wounded in the fighting on Wednesday in the Achin district of the Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that approximately seven other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nAn American soldier was killed in a battle with ISIS in Afghanistan on Wednesday. Pictured above, US forces and Afghan commando patrol Pandola village near the site of a US bombing in the Achin district of Jalalabad, east of Kabul, Afghanistan in April (file photo)\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\n'Today we lost one soldier from the Utah National Guard,' Maj. Gen. Burton said, according to news reports. 'Initially it was seven wounded, that number has gone up to eleven.'\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled US-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nA US military helicopter flies over the site of a suicide bomb that struck a NATO convoy in Kandahar south of Kabul, Afghanistan earlier this month (file photo)\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an 'open letter' to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new US military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster US counterterrorism operations.\n\nThe deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8823529481887817, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9769057", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "566"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CBImages/?media=photo&contentId=4a0cbbf9e54744f383e1d0e55ae5ae61&fmt=jpg&Role=Preview&reldt=2017-08-15T10:18:36GMT&authToken=eNoNwjsOwCAIANATkUD5iAOHUYuJW8cOHl5f3s4%2fjI3dnJUcL0fbY4U0HL3PCqlSQGQyOCfBi6na8jba64uHWM0LUj0OaRQw", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-17-AS--Afghanistan/id-6da0a84a12fa44459b52bbecae71275a", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:06:00", "title": "US soldier killed in battle with IS in Afghanistan", "uri": "711090179", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:53:00Z", "time": "19:53:00", "body": "KABUL, Afghanistan (AP) -- An American soldier was killed and several others were wounded in a battle with Islamic State militants in eastern Afghanistan, the U.S. military said.\n\nThe military said in a statement that several Afghan forces were also wounded in the fighting on Wednesday in the Achin district of the Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that 11 other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nHe was clearing a building when a booby trap exploded, killed him and injured the other 11 members of the team, said Utah Gov. Gary Herbert.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nThe family of the slain solider identified him as Aaron Butler, 27, of Monticello, Utah. His father Randy Butler said in a statement he was a champion high school wrestler who became a Green Beret after graduating from the U.S. Army Special Forces qualification course with honors in 2016.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Mirwais Khan in Kandahar, Afghanistan, and Lindsay Whitehurst in Salt Lake City contributed to this report.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100, "id": 161, {"sim": 0.8745098114013672, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9780408", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "actionnewsjax.com", "title": "WJAX", "id": "1040"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://cmgfeeds.cmgdigital.com/photo/2017/08/17/Afghanistan_Taliban_Trump_69581_8883512_ver1.0_1280_720.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.actionnewsjax.com/news/us-soldier-killed-in-battle-with-is-in-afghanistan/594179583", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:29:00", "title": "US soldier killed in battle with IS in Afghanistan", "uri": "711123875", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T21:29:00Z", "time": "21:29:00", "body": "The military said in a statement that several Afghan forces were also wounded in the fighting on Wednesday in the Achin district of the Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that 11 other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nHe was clearing a building when a booby trap exploded, killed him and injured the other 11 members of the team, said Utah Gov. Gary Herbert.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nThe family of the slain solider identified him as Aaron Butler, 27, of Monticello, Utah. His father Randy Butler said in a statement he was a champion high school wrestler who became a Green Beret after graduating from the U.S. Army Special Forces qualification course with honors in 2016.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Mirwais Khan in Kandahar, Afghanistan, and Lindsay Whitehurst in Salt Lake City contributed to this report.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100, "id": 161, {"sim": 0.8745098114013672, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9705782", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "detroitnews.com", "title": "The Detroit News", "id": "2989"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": null, "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.detroitnews.com/story/news/world/2017/08/17/afghanistan/104678920/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:10:00", "title": "US soldier killed in battle with IS in Afghanistan", "uri": "710924191", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T14:10:00Z", "time": "14:10:00", "body": "CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nKabul, Afghanistan -- An American soldier was killed and several others were wounded in a battle with Islamic State militants in eastern Afghanistan, the U.S. military said.\n\nThe military said in a statement that several Afghan forces were also wounded in the fighting on Wednesday in the Achin district of the Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that approximately seven other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:48:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban warns US on sending more troops - Taipei Times", "uri": "710437976", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T16:48:00Z", "time": "16:48:00", "body": "A US military helicopter flies over the site of a suicide bomb that struck a NATO convoy in Kandahar, Afghanistan, on Aug. 2.\n\nThe Taliban on Tuesday told US President Donald Trump in an open letter that the military situation in Afghanistan was \"far worse than you realize\" and that sending in more troops would be self-destructive.\n\nA senior Taliban official said the rare decision to address Trump directly was timed to coincide with the president's deliberations on the future of US policy in Afghanistan.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the lengthy English-language letter.\n\n'STOOGES'\n\nThe Taliban criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges,\" \"lying, corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who were providing Washington with \"rosy pictures\" of the military position.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Muslim rule, has waged an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led invasion after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks on the US.\n\nThose attacks were planned by then-al-Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden from a base in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize,\" the letter said, adding that the only thing preventing the Taliban from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nInfluential voices, including US Senator John McCain, have also urged an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nSKEPTICISM\n\nHowever, such plans have faced skepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticized years of US military intervention and foreign aid.\n\nUS Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis on Monday told reporters that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table.\n\nHowever, US officials believe it could take weeks for a South Asia strategy to be approved.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the Taliban told Trump.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan, because they seek to preserve their military privileges,\" the group said.\n\nSome Taliban leaders disagreed with publishing the letter as they believe the group is close to being able to end the war on its own terms, while the \"Americans are no longer in a position to fight this never-ending war,\" one Taliban official said.\n\nThe first official said the Taliban was open to \"discuss all issues with the United States for bringing peace to Afghanistan\" if US troops are withdrawn.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban letter said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world, but if anyone violates Influential voices including Republican Senator John McCain have also urged an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nBut such plans have faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticized years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\nUS Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table. However, U.S officials believe it could take weeks for a South Asia strategy to be approved.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the Taliban told Trump.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nSome Taliban leaders disagreed with publishing the letter as they believe the group is close to being able to end the war on its own terms, while the \"Americans are no longer in a position to fight this never-ending war,\" one Taliban official said.\n\nThe first official said the Taliban was open to \"discuss all issues with the United States for bringing peace to Afghanistan\" if American troops are withdrawn.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban letter said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention toward the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating "http://www.scmp.com/news/world/middle-east/article/2106936/taliban-urge-trump-withdraw-all-us-troops-afghanistan", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:45:00", "title": "Taliban urge Trump to stop listening to 'stooges' in Kabul and withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan", "uri": "709873321", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:45:00Z", "time": "16:45:00", "body": "The United States should withdraw all its troops from Afghanistan and stop listening to \"stooges\" in Kabul, the Taliban warned in an open letter to US President Donald Trump on Tuesday.\n\nThe Trump administration is working to finalise a regional strategy that could include nearly 4,000 additional US troops, part of a Nato-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\nUS air strike kills senior Islamic State commanders in Afghanistan\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the long statement, the Taliban criticised the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sell-outs\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realise!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nPowerful voices in the US government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nNato agrees to send more troops to Afghanistan but not in combat roles\n\nUS Defence Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table.\n\nUS officials believe a South Asia strategy is not imminent and could take weeks until it is approved.\n\nThe Taliban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and {"sim": 0.8588235378265381, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9349296", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/05/taliban-759.jpg?w=759", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 32, "textEnd": 47, "date": "2017-08-16", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1508, "textEnd": 1516, "date": "2017-09-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/afghan-taliban-warns-donald-trump-against-sending-in-more-troops-to-afghanistan-4798561/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:59:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban warns Donald Trump against sending in more troops to Afghanistan", "uri": "709952627", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T19:59:00Z", "time": "19:59:00", "body": "By: Reuters | Kabul | Published:August 16, 2017 1:08 am \"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the lengthy English-language letter. Taliban urge Donald Trump to withdraw all US troops from AfghanistanUS president Donald Trump faces backlash over handling of Charlottesville upheavalDonald Trump orders probe into China's trade practices, Beijing warns of retaliation\n\nThe Taliban told US President Donald Trump in an open letter on Tuesday that the military situation in Afghanistan was \"far worse than you realize\", and sending in more troops would be self-destructive. A senior Taliban official told Reuters the rare decision to address Trump directly was timed to coincide with the president's deliberations on the future of US policy in Afghanistan. \"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the lengthy English-language letter.\n\nIt criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying, corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who were providing Washington with \"rosy pictures\" of the military position. The Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, has waged an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led invasion after the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001. Those attacks were planned by al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden from a base in Afghanistan. \"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the letter said, arguing that the only thing preventing the Taliban from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces. Influential voices including Republican Senator John McCain have also urged an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nBut such plans have faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\nUS Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table. However, US officials believe it could take weeks for a South Asia strategy to be approved.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the Taliban told Trump.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nSome Taliban leaders disagreed with publishing the letter as they believe the group is close to being able to end the war on its own terms, while the \"Americans are no longer in a position to fight this never-ending war,\" one Taliban official said.\n\nThe first official said the Taliban was open to \"discuss all issues with the United States for bringing peace to Afghanistan\" if American troops are withdrawn. \"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban letter said. \"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\"\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: 9/11 Afghanistan donald trump Taliban US", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8549019694328308, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9699530", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "hawaiinewsnow.com", "title": "KHNL TV 8", "id": "11710"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://APMOBILE.images.worldnow.com/images/14678167_G.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/36156845/us-soldier-killed-in-battle-with-is-in-afghanistan", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:39:00", "title": "US soldier killed in battle with IS in Afghanistan", "uri": "710909103", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:39:00Z", "time": "13:39:00", "body": "KABUL, Afghanistan (AP) - An American soldier was killed and several others were wounded in a battle with Islamic State militants in eastern Afghanistan, the U.S. military said.\n\nThe military said in a statement that several Afghan forces were also wounded in the fighting on Wednesday in the Achin district of the Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that approximately seven other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Mirwais Khan in Kandahar, Afghanistan, contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"sim": 0.8549019694328308, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9336674", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "the-star.co.ke", "title": "The Star", "id": "1875"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://www.the-star.co.ke/sites/default/files/styles/open_graph/public/1617462.jpg?itok=7wKI4G2r", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 986, "textEnd": 998, "date": "2017-09-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/08/15/afghan-taliban-warns-trump-against-sending-in-more-troops_c1617461", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:29:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban warns Trump against sending in more troops", "uri": "709917852", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T18:29:00Z", "time": "18:29:00", "body": "The Taliban told US President Donald Trump in an open letter on Tuesday that the military situation in Afghanistan was \"far worse than you realize\", and sending in more troops would be self-destructive.\n\nA senior Taliban official told Reuters the rare decision to address Trump directly was timed to coincide with the president's deliberations on the future of US policy in Afghanistan.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the lengthy English-language letter.\n\nIt criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying, corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who were providing Washington with \"rosy pictures\" of the military position.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, has waged an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led invasion after the September 11 attacks in 2001. Those attacks were planned by al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden from a base in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the letter said, arguing that the only thing preventing the Taliban from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces. Influential voices including Republican Senator John McCain have also urged an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nBut such plans have faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\nUS Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table.\n\nHowever, US officials believe it could take weeks for a South Asia strategy to be approved.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the Taliban told Trump.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nSome Taliban leaders disagreed with publishing the letter as they believe the group is close to being able to end the war on its own terms, while the \"Americans are no longer in a position to fight this never-ending war,\" one Taliban official said.\n\nThe first official said the Taliban was open to \"discuss all issues with the United States for bringing peace to Afghanistan\" if American troops are withdrawn.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban letter said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\"", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "http://zeenews.india.com/world/taliban-urge-donald-trump-to-withdraw-all-us-troops-from-afghanistan-2033202.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:45:00", "title": "Taliban urge Donald Trump to withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan", "uri": "709819042", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:45:00Z", "time": "14:45:00", "body": "Kabul: The United States should withdraw all its troops from Afghanistan and stop listening to \"stooges\" in Kabul, the Taliban warned in an open letter to U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday.\n\nThe Trump administration is working to finalize a regional strategy that could include nearly 4,000 additional US troops, part of a NATO-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than the further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a U.S.-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy statement, the Taliban criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior U.S. commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nPowerful voices in the US government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" U.S. military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nUS Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table.\n\nUS officials believe a South Asia strategy is not imminent and could take weeks until it is approved.\n\nThe Taliban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they {"sim": 0.8470588326454163, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9313168", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dnaindia.com", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "id": "492"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 992, "textEnd": 1000, "date": "2017-09-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-afghan-taliban-warns-trump-against-sending-in-more-troops-2530983", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:04:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban warns Trump against sending in more troops", "uri": "709854569", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T16:04:00Z", "time": "16:04:00", "body": "The Taliban told U.S. President Donald Trump in an open letter on Tuesday that the military situation in Afghanistan was \"far worse than you realize\", and sending in more troops would be self-destructive.\n\nA senior Taliban official told Reuters the rare decision to address Trump directly was timed to coincide with the president's deliberations on the future of U.S. policy in Afghanistan.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the lengthy English-language letter.\n\nIt criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying, corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who were providing Washington with \"rosy pictures\" of the military position.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, has waged an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a U.S.-led invasion after the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001. Those attacks were planned by al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden from a base in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the letter said, arguing that the only thing preventing the Taliban from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe senior U.S. commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nInfluential voices including Republican Senator John McCain have also urged an \"enduring\" U.S. military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nBut such plans have faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\nU.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table. However, U.S officials believe it could take weeks for a South Asia strategy to be approved.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the Taliban told Trump.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nSome Taliban leaders disagreed with publishing the letter as they believe the group is close to being able to end the war on its own terms, while the \"Americans are no longer in a position to fight this never-ending war,\" one Taliban official said.\n\nThe first official said the Taliban was open to \"discuss all issues with the United States for bringing peace to Afghanistan\" if American troops are withdrawn.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban letter said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\"\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's editorial team and is auto-generated from an agency feed.)", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": include nearly 4,000 additional U.S. troops, part of a NATO-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a U.S.-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy statement, the Taliban criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior U.S. commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nPowerful voices in the U.S. government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" U.S. military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nU.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table.\n\nU.S officials believe a South Asia strategy is not imminent and could take weeks until it is approved.\n\nThe Taliban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating Islamic rule in Afghanistan. -- Reuters picKABUL, Aug 15 -- The United States should withdraw all its troops from Afghanistan and stop listening to \"stooges\" in Kabul, the Taliban warned in an open letter to US President Donald Trump today.\n\nThe Trump administration is working to finalise a regional strategy that could include nearly 4,000 additional US troops, part of a NATO-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy statement, the Taliban criticised the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nPowerful voices in the US government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nThe Taliban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that approximately seven other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Mirwais Khan in "http://www.dnaindia.com/world/report-taliban-urge-trump-to-withdraw-all-us-troops-from-afghanistan-2530755", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "11:20:00", "title": "Taliban urge Trump to withdraw all U.S. troops from Afghanistan", "uri": "709726639", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T11:20:00Z", "time": "11:20:00", "body": "The United States should withdraw all its troops from Afghanistan and stop listening to \"stooges\" in Kabul, the Taliban warned in an open letter to U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday.\n\nThe Trump administration is working to finalise a regional strategy that could include nearly 4,000 additional U.S. troops, part of a NATO-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a U.S.-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy statement, the Taliban criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior U.S. commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nPowerful voices in the U.S. government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" U.S. military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nThe Taliban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\"\n\n(This article has not been edited by DNA's coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced skepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticized years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy statement, the Taliban criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges,\" \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to Sgt. Aaron Butler paid the ultimate sacrifice for our country.\n\n\"The Army values are: 'Loyalty, Duty, Respect, Selfless-Service, Honor, Integrity, Personal Courage'. Aaron Butler personified those values in everything he said and did. In a life that was all too brief, our dear son and brother made the ultimate sacrifice for his country. While we are heartbroken to become a Gold Star family, we honor Aaron's service and sacrifice. Aaron was a strength to us, an inspiration to those around him, and a joy to have in our family.\"\n\nHis family says says Butler and his 11 other team members of Utah's National Guard were sweeping for security when an explosive device went off. The blast killed Butler and injured the 11 other Guard members. Eight of the 11 injured live in the Beehive state.\n\nThe group was working with members of the Afghan Army on a ground mission fighting members of the Islamic State in eastern Afghanistan.\n\nHis family says Sgt. Butler is one of four soldiers who graduated with honors from the Army Green Beret Special Forces Qualification course in January 2016.\n\n\"Aaron was absolutely fearless, selfless, courageous and relentless,\" his father Randy said.\n\nButler graduated from Monticello High School in 2008. He was a four-time high school state wrestling champ. After graduating he served an LDS mission in Ghana from 2009-2011.\n\nSgt. Butler is the first Utah Guard member who died in Afghanistan since 2010, according to Gov. Herbert.\n\nHis body is being flown to Dover, Maryland. {"sim": 0.8274509906768799, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9310186", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "title": "Mail Online", "id": "214"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 43, "textEnd": 49, "date": "2017-08-15", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1054, "textEnd": 1062, "date": "2017-09-11", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4792960/index.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:49:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban warns Trump against sending in more troops", "uri": "709847152", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:49:00Z", "time": "15:49:00", "body": "By Josh Smith and Mushtaq Yusufzai\n\nKABUL, Aug 15 (Reuters) - The Taliban told U.S. President Donald Trump in an open letter on Tuesday that the military situation in Afghanistan was \"far worse than you realize\", and sending in more troops would be self-destructive.\n\nA senior Taliban official told Reuters the rare decision to address Trump directly was timed to coincide with the president's deliberations on the future of U.S. policy in Afghanistan.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the lengthy English-language letter.\n\nIt criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying, corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who were providing Washington with \"rosy pictures\" of the military position.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, has waged an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a U.S.-led invasion after the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001. Those attacks were planned by al Qaeda leader Osama bin Laden from a base in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the letter said, arguing that the only thing preventing the Taliban from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe senior U.S. commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces. Influential voices including Republican Senator John McCain have also urged an \"enduring\" U.S. military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nBut such plans have faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\nU.S. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on Monday that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table. However, U.S officials believe it could take weeks for a South Asia strategy to be approved.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the Taliban told Trump.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nSome Taliban leaders disagreed with publishing the letter as they believe the group is close to being able to end the war on its own terms, while the \"Americans are no longer in a position to fight this never-ending war,\" one Taliban official said.\n\nThe first official said the Taliban was open to \"discuss all issues with the United States for bringing peace to Afghanistan\" if American troops are withdrawn.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban letter said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\" (Additional reporting by Idrees Ali in Washington; Editing by Mark Trevelyan)", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": "709728752", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T11:24:00Z", "time": "11:24:00", "body": "By Josh Smith\n\nKABUL, Aug 15 (Reuters) - The United States should withdraw all its troops from Afghanistan and stop listening to \"stooges\" in Kabul, the Taliban warned in an open letter to U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday.\n\nThe Trump administration is working to finalise a regional strategy that could include nearly 4,000 additional U.S. troops, part of a NATO-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a U.S.-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy statement, the Taliban criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior U.S. commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nPowerful voices in the U.S. government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" U.S. military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nThe Taliban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban said.\n\n\"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\" (Editing by Nick Macfie)", "date": "2017-08-15",
