It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that approximately seven other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\n--\n\nAssociated Press writers Mirwais Khan in They mainly serve as trainers and advisers to Afghan forces.\n\nTrump's administration is currently finalising a new policy for Afghanistan almost 16 years after the US invasion to topple the Taliban regime. American military commanders in Afghanistan have requested thousands of extra boots on the ground to help combat a resurgent Taliban.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis is believed to be close to presenting the new US military strategy to Trump, with an announcement potentially coming in weeks.\n\nThe Taliban, which ruled Afghanistan from 1996-2001, also slammed the Afghan government in the letter and warned the United States that it could never defeat the insurgent group.\n\n\"It is entirely possible that you are being provided rosy pictures about Afghanistan by the stooges you have installed,\" it said. \"You must realise that these repulsive sellouts neither care about your interests nor that of their own nation,\" the statement added.\n\nThe letter described foreign occupation as the \"main driver of war\" in Afghanistan and ended by making reference to reports that Trump may be considering outsourcing operations to private contractors.\n\nIn recent months, Erik Prince - founder of the private security company Blackwater - has resurfaced with an offer to send a private army of around 5,500 contractors to replace the US troops.\n\n\"If you failed to win the Afghan war with disciplined US and NATO troops... you shall never be able to win it with mercenaries, notorious contractor firms and immoral stooges,\" it said.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.8117647171020508, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368635", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9696805", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "566"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CBImages/?media=photo&contentId=4a0cbbf9e54744f383e1d0e55ae5ae61&fmt=jpg&Role=Preview&reldt=2017-08-15T10:18:36GMT&authToken=eNoNwjsOwCAIANATkUD5iAOHUYuJW8cOHl5f3s4%2fjI3dtIoSXo6yxwppOHqfFVKlgMhkcE6CF1O15W201xcPsZoXpHoADcUULQ%3d%3d", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/0260ea4c3e85456b80715585ba3c7b5b/Article_2017-08-17-AS-Afghanistan/id-f91d420650d743b7b39b60134fe9f9f1", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:25:00", "title": "US soldier killed in battle with IS in Afghanistan", "uri": "710901543", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T13:23:00Z", "time": "13:23:00", "body": "KABUL, Afghanistan (AP) -- An American soldier was killed and several others were wounded in a battle with Islamic State militants in eastern Afghanistan, the U.S. military said.\n\nThe military said in a statement that several Afghan forces were also wounded in the fighting on Wednesday in the Achin district of the Nangarhar province, a militant stronghold. It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nAnd in three southern provinces, Taliban attacks on Wednesday killed a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen, Afghan officials said Thursday.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said the American soldier who died was one of its members and that approximately seven other National Guardsmen were among the wounded. The names were withheld pending notification of family members.\n\nThe wounded soldiers were evacuated for medical treatment.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe IS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late on Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late on Wednesday, killing seven policemen and wounding nine, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. He said 19 Taliban were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnd in southern Zabul province, the Taliban attacked a police base, killing eight policemen.\n\nA police official, Asif Tokhi, said the attack started on Wednesday night, along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, where the base is located.\n\nFighting there continued into the morning Thursday, he said. Along with the eight killed, three policemen were also wounded, and 12 Taliban fighters were also killed, Tokhi added.\n\nThe Taliban made no statements on the latest attacks.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Taliban released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war and warning against new U.S. military buildup in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Mirwais Khan in {"sim": 0.8117647171020508, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9295153", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "title": "The Express Tribune", "id": "1929"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://c.tribune.com.pk/2017/08/1482189-donaldtrump-1502805136-318-640x480.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/1482189/afghan-taliban-warn-trump-troop-increase-open-letter/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:21:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban warn Trump against troop increase in open letter", "uri": "709809253", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:21:00Z", "time": "14:21:00", "body": "KABUL: Afghan Taliban published an open letter to US President Donald Trump on Tuesday warning him against sending more American forces to Afghanistan.\n\nThe statement called for the complete withdrawal of foreign forces from the war-torn country and comes as Trump weighs increasing the number of American troops there.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might.\n\n\"Therefore it would be wise if you adopt the strategy of a complete withdrawal from Afghanistan instead of a troops increase,\" said the English-language letter, which was sent to the media.\n\nTaliban advise Trump to review Afghan policy\n\nUS troops in Afghanistan now number about 8,400, a far cry from the US presence of more than 100,000 six years ago. They mainly serve as trainers and advisers to Afghan forces.\n\nTrump's administration is currently finalising a new policy for Afghanistan almost 16 years after the US invasion to topple the Taliban regime.\n\nAmerican military commanders in Afghanistan have requested thousands of extra boots on the ground to help combat a resurgent Taliban.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis is believed to be close to presenting the new US military strategy to Trump, with an announcement potentially coming in weeks.\n\nThe Taliban, which ruled Afghanistan from 1996-2001, also slammed the Afghan government in the letter and warned the United States that it could never defeat the insurgent group.\n\n\"It is entirely possible that you are being provided rosy pictures about Afghanistan by the stooges you have installed,\" it said.\n\n\"You must realise that these repulsive sellouts neither care about your interests nor that of their own nation,\" the statement added.\n\nThe letter described foreign occupation as the \"main driver of war\" in Afghanistan and ended by making reference to reports that Trump may be considering outsourcing operations to private contractors.\n\nIn recent months, Erik Prince - founder of the private security company Blackwater - has resurfaced with an offer to send a private army of around 5,500 contractors to replace the US troops.\n\n\"If you failed to win the Afghan war with disciplined US and NATO troops... you shall never be able to win it with mercenaries, notorious contractor firms and immoral stooges,\" it said.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realise!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering {"sim": 0.8117647171020508, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9293085", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/08/donald-trump-7597.jpg?w=759", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 32, "textEnd": 47, "date": "2017-08-15", "amb": false}], "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/taliban-urge-donald-trump-to-withdraw-all-us-troops-from-afghanistan-4798310/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:10:00", "title": "Taliban urge Donald Trump to withdraw all US troops from Afghanistan", "uri": "709803830", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T14:10:00Z", "time": "14:10:00", "body": "By: Reuters | Kabul | Published:August 15, 2017 7:39 pm US President Donald Trump (File) US president Donald Trump faces backlash over handling of Charlottesville upheavalDonald Trump orders probe into China's trade practices, Beijing warns of retaliationAnalysis: To launch or not? Either way, North Korea's Kim Jong Un may gain\n\nThe United States should withdraw all its troops from Afghanistan and stop listening to \"stooges\" in Kabul, the Taliban warned in an open letter to US President Donald Trump on Tuesday.\n\nThe Trump administration is working to finalise a regional strategy that could include nearly 4,000 additional US troops, part of a NATO-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country. That plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nThe Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led military operation in 2001. In the lengthy statement, the Taliban criticized the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic \"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties. The statement also took aim at generals, who the Taliban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces. Powerful voices in the US government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nThe Taliban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops. \"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taliban said. \"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\"\n\nFor all John Nicholson, who has been commander of U.S. forces in Afghanistan since March 2016.In February, Nicholson was the first to call the war a stalemate and said he needed a few thousand more troops to break it.\n\nAbout 1,600 words long letter drew attention of U.S. President ,saying that pulling out of Afghanistan would \"truly deliver American troops from harm's way\" and bring about \"an end to an inherited war.\"\n\nTerming Afghanistan as 'a mess' that he took over from the previous administration,U.S. President Donald Trump said that his administration is getting close to a decision on an updated strategy for the war in Afghanistan.\n\nUS Defence Secretary James Mattis has indicated that Trump's new strategy for Afghanistan would have a regional context, including a Pakistan angle.The new Afghan strategy may include sending close to 5,000 additional troops to Afghanistan and also changing somewhat what the troops on the ground are doing right now\".\n\nThe Afghan government was assessed by the US military to control or influence just 59.7 per cent of Afghanistan's 407 districts as of Feb 20, a nearly 11 percentage-point decrease from the same time in 2016, according to data released by the US Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction, the Dawn reported\n\nU.S. National Security Adviser Gen H.R. McMaster conveyed the stern message of President Donald Trump to Pakistan to change its 'paradoxical' policy of supporting the Taliban, Haqqani network and other militants who are causing the country great losses.\n\nThe U.S. officials have often accused Pakistan of helping the militants, a charge Islamabad vehemently denies, but this marks the first time that the allegation has been attributed to {"sim": 0.8078431487083435, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3371876", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9769224", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "stgeorgeutah.com", "title": "St George News", "id": "3138"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://www.stgeorgeutah.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/aaron-bulter-stgnews-FI-1024x619.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 3278, "textEnd": 3293, "date": "2017-08-17", "freq": 2, "amb": false}, {"textStart": 1656, "textEnd": 1668, "date": "2016-01-", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.stgeorgeutah.com/news/archive/2017/08/17/mgk-utah-national-guard-member-killed-in-afghanistan/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:08:00", "title": "Utah National Guard member killed in Afghanistan", "uri": "711091117", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T20:08:00Z", "time": "20:08:00", "body": "ST. GEORGE - A 27-year-old Utah National Guard member from San Juan County was killed in Afghanistan Wednesday when a building he and his team were clearing exploded. The incident also left 11 others injured.\n\nGov. Gary Herbert confirmed Thursday during a press conference that a 12-member team of the Utah National Guard had been involved in an incident in a \"booby-trapped\" building that turned deadly for Aaron Butler, 27, of Monticello, Utah.\n\nWhile the governor did not release any names of the soldiers involved, Butler was subsequently identified as the soldier who had been killed. His family released the following statement Thursday:\n\nThe Army values are: 'Loyalty, Duty, Respect, Selfless-Service, Honor, Integrity, Personal Courage'. Aaron Butler personified those values in everything he said and did. In a life that was all too brief, our dear son and brother made the ultimate sacrifice for his country. While we are heartbroken to become a Gold Star family, we honor Aaron's service and sacrifice. Aaron was a strength to us, an inspiration to those around him, and a joy to have in our family.\n\nEight members of the National Guard team are from Utah, Herbert said, while three are from other states. Each suffered \"various degrees of injury,\" the governor said.\n\n\"I will be calling and contacting the families today that have been involved in this incident to let them know of our concern and our support and our condolences. Certainly, it's a tragedy for them and a tragedy for all of us,\" Herbert said.\n\nAccording to the San Juan Record, Butler was a Special Forces Green Beret and graduated with honors from the qualification course in January 2016.\n\nA press release from the National Guard said Butler's team was in eastern Afghanistan and engaged in operations against ISIS groups in the region.\n\n\"My heart aches for the loss and sacrifice of our members and their families,\" Maj. Gen. Jefferson Burton, adjutant general of the Utah National Guard, said Wednesday. \"I know that what we do is dangerous and important work for our country's defense, but this realization does little to console me during times of loss such as this.\"\n\nThe San Jan County Commission also released a statement Thursday.\n\nYesterday, while on a mission in Afghanistan, Aaron Butler was killed by enemy forces.\n\nOur hearts are broken. We are devastated. Our prayers and support are sent to the Butler family at this sad time.\n\nWe will remember Aaron as a man that gave his life so that we may continue to live in the land of the free. His selfless service will not go unremembered or unthanked because we will remember and show gratitude to his family.\n\nWe also send our prayers to the other members of Aaron's unit that were wounded during the mission and wish them a speedy recovery.\n\nMay we never take our freedoms for granted or let a day go by without showing gratitude to the men and women who fight for our country.\n\nButler's body is being flown to Dover, Maryland, and will eventually be released to the family.\n\nMembers of Utah's Congressional delegation also expressed their condolences over social media.\n\nMy heart goes out to the family of the Guardsman we lost in Afghanistan. It's reminder that we live in a dangerous world.\n\n-- Rep. Chris Stewart (@RepChrisStewart) August 17, 2017\n\nBrave me & women and their families sacrifice every day to help protect us. On behalf of all you Utah's we are grateful for their sacrifice\n\n-- Rep. who are supposed to be in a non-combat role in Afghanistan - killed in action in the country so far this year to 10, one above the tally for the whole of 2016.\n\n\"One US service member has died as a result of wounds suffered Wednesday during a partnered operation with US and Afghan forces in Eastern Afghanistan,\" United States Forces-Afghanistan said in a statement.\n\n\"US and Afghan forces were also injured during the operation aimed at further reducing Islamic State of Iraq and Syria-Khorasan presence in Afghanistan,\" it said, referring to the IS group's regional affiliate.\n\nThe wounded were later evacuated for treatment, the statement added.\n\nEarlier this month two US soldiers were killed in Kandahar when a Taliban suicide bomber rammed a vehicle filled with explosives into their convoy.\n\nThe deaths come as President Donald Trump considers sending more troops to Afghanistan to help beat back a resurgent Taliban and an increasing IS presence.\n\nUS forces have been regularly targeting IS fighters in Afghanistan since the insurgents gained a foothold in the east of the country in 2015.\n\nSeveral leaders of the group's Afghan affiliate were killed by the US in recent months, which says it wants to defeat the militant group by the end of the year.\n\nIn April, the US military dropped the so-called \"Mother of All Bombs\" on IS hideouts in a complex of tunnels and bunkers in eastern Nangarhar province, killing over 90 militants.\n\nThe Pentagon said the GBU-43/B Massive Ordnance Air Blast device was the biggest non-nuclear weapon it had ever used in combat.\n\nIS continues to wreak havoc in the war-torn country. recognised the errors of his predecessors by seeking a review of the US strategy for Afghanistan.\n\nMujahid said Trump should not hand control of the US Afghan policy to the military but rather, announce the withdrawal of US forces and not an increase in troops as the Trump administration has planned.\n\nThe note, which is 1,600 words long, also says a US withdrawal would \"truly deliver American troops from harm's way\" and bring about \"an end to an inherited war.\"\n\nUS Defence Secretary James Mattis in July said that the Trump administration's new strategy for Afghanistan would have a regional context, including a Pakistan angle.\n\nHe said that while media speculations about the Trump administration sending close to 5,000 additional troops to Afghanistan \"may turn out to be right\", the new strategy \"also involves, perhaps, changing somewhat what the troops on the ground are doing right now\".\n\nSome US officials have questioned the benefit of sending more troops to Afghanistan because any politically palatable number would not be enough to turn the tide, much less create stability and security.\n\nTo date, more than 2,300 Americans have been killed and more than 17,000 wounded since the war began in 2001.\n\nAny increase of several thousand troops would leave American forces in Afghanistan well below their 2011 peak of more than 100,000 troops.\n\nThe Afghan government was assessed by the US military to control or influence just 59.7 per cent of Afghanistan's 407 districts as of Feb 20, a nearly 11 percentage-point decrease from the same time in 2016, Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban stated in 1,600-word English-language letter, released to the media through spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid.\n\nThe letter accused \"warmongering\" generals and politicians of prolonging the conflict and claiming more and more American and Afghan lives.\n\nThe militants said that the only true path to peace was an end to the American presence in the country.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the letter the transgressors.\"\n\nThe letter claims that Afghan officials are downplaying the seriousness of the situation and that only a fear of causing mass civilian casualties is holding the Taliban back from a large-scale offensive.\n\nThough Trump himself has previously criticized US interventionism abroad, his administration is considering a new strategy there, which could see deploying thousands They mainly serve as trainers and advisers to Afghan forces.\n\nTrump's administration is currently finalising a new policy for Afghanistan almost 16 years after the US invasion to topple the Taliban regime.\n\nAmerican military commanders in Afghanistan have requested thousands of extra boots on the ground to help combat a resurgent Taliban.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis is believed to be close to presenting the new US military strategy to Trump, with an announcement potentially coming in weeks.\n\nThe Taliban, which ruled Afghanistan from 1996-2001, also slammed the Afghan government in the letter and warned the United States that it could never defeat the insurgent group.\n\n\"It is entirely possible that you are being provided rosy pictures about Afghanistan by the stooges you have installed,\" it said.\n\n\"You must realize that these repulsive sellouts neither care about your interests nor that of their own nation,\" the statement added.\n\nThe letter described foreign occupation as the \"main driver of war\" in Afghanistan and ended by making reference to reports that Trump may be considering outsourcing operations to private contractors.\n\nIn recent months, Erik Prince -- founder of the private security company Blackwater -- has resurfaced with an offer to send a private army of around 5,500 contractors to replace the US troops.\n\n\"If you failed to win the Afghan war with disciplined US and NATO troops... you shall never be able to win it with mercenaries, notorious contractor firms and immoral stooges,\" it said.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": They mainly serve as trainers and advisers to Afghan forces.\n\nTrump's administration is currently finalising a new policy for Afghanistan almost 16 years after the US invasion to topple the Taliban regime.\n\nAmerican military commanders in Afghanistan have requested thousands of extra boots on the ground to help combat a resurgent Taliban.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis is believed to be close to presenting the new US military strategy to Trump, with an announcement potentially coming in weeks.\n\nThe Taliban, which ruled Afghanistan from 1996-2001, also slammed the Afghan government in the letter and warned the United States that it could never defeat the insurgent group.\n\n\"It is entirely possible that you are being provided rosy pictures about Afghanistan by the stooges you have installed,\" it said.\n\n\"You must realize that these repulsive sellouts neither care about your interests nor that of their own nation,\" the statement added.\n\nThe letter described foreign occupation as the \"main driver of war\" in Afghanistan and ended by making reference to reports that Trump may be considering outsourcing operations to private contractors.\n\nIn recent months, Erik Prince -- founder of the private security company Blackwater -- has resurfaced with an offer to send a private army of around 5,500 contractors to replace the US troops.\n\n\"If you failed to win the "710184589", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T07:57:00Z", "time": "07:57:00", "body": "TEHRAN (FNA)- The Taliban terrorist group released an open letter to US President Donald Trump, in which the groups calls for a complete withdrawal of US forces from Afghanistan, saying they provoke ongoing violence in the country, local media said.\n\nIn their letter, the group has claimed that the ongoing violence in Afghanistan had a direct link to the presence of US forces, calling them \"occupation forces\" that provoke war in Afghanistan used by everyone in their own interest, Khaama Press reported.\n\nThe group also accused the US-led coalition for the destruction of the country that has made Afghanistan one of the worst nations in terms of security, governance, and economy.\n\nAfghan Army Launches Operation to Retake Village Controlled by Taliban, ISIL\n\nThe Taliban has released the new letter amid the Trump administration's review of Afghanistan policy.\n\nAfghanistan has long been suffering from unstable political, social and security situation due to the simmering militant insurgency, including that of Taliban and ISIL terrorist groups.\n\nThe United States and its allies launched a military operation in Afghanistan in 2001 following 9/11 terror attacks. The mission in Afghanistan ended in 2014. On January 1, 2015, NATO announced its new mission in the country, called Resolute Support, to train and assist the Afghan security forces. More than 8,400 US troops remain in Afghanistan with an additional 5,000 NATO forces.\n\nOn July 14, Defense Secretary James Mattis said the Pentagon was close to completing its policy review for a new strategy in Afghanistan. On August 3, US Sen. Lindsey Graham said the United States could turn the tide of the war in Afghanistan with just 3,000-4,000 additional troops and boosted air capacity.\n\nLast week, US Sen. John McCain introduced an amendment that details a strategy to resolve the ongoing conflict in Afghanistan, while Trump said his administration was getting closer to making a major decision on They mainly serve as trainers and advisers to Afghan forces.\n\nTrump's administration is currently finalising a new policy for Afghanistan almost 16 years after the US invasion to topple the Taliban regime.\n\nAmerican military commanders in Afghanistan have requested thousands of extra boots on the ground to help combat a resurgent Taliban.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis is believed to be close to presenting the new US military strategy to Trump, with an announcement potentially coming in weeks.\n\nThe Taliban, which ruled Afghanistan from 1996-2001, also slammed the Afghan government in the letter and warned the United States that it could never defeat the insurgent group.\n\n\"It is entirely possible that you are being provided rosy pictures about Afghanistan by the stooges you have installed,\" it said. \"You must realize that these repulsive sellouts neither care about your interests nor that of their own nation,\" the statement added.\n\nThe letter described foreign occupation as the \"main driver of war\" in Afghanistan and ended by making reference to reports that Trump may be considering outsourcing operations to private contractors.\n\nPentagon chief Jim Mattis said Monday he backs the top US commander in Afghanistan - after President Donald Trump reportedly suggested firing him.\n\nNBC News this month said Trump had told Mattis and General Joe Dunford, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, they should replace General John Nicholson, who heads up US and NATO forces in Afghanistan.\n\nNicholson \"is our commander in the field. He has the confidence of NATO, he has the confidence of Afghanistan, he has the confidence of the United States,\" Mattis told Pentagon reporters.\n\nTrump \"is looking at all aspects of our effort over there, as he must in his responsibilities as the commander-in-chief,\" Mattis added. When asked if he personally backed Nicholson staying in the job, Mattis said: \"Of course.\"\n\nTrump has yet to announce a strategy for Afghanistan, but Mattis said one is \"very, very close.\" Omar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker was killed in the blast while three other militants on foot were shot dead when guards opened fire on them. He said the explosion also left three Afghan forces injured.\n\nSeven policemen were killed and nine were wounded in two similar attacks by the Taliban on police checkpoints in two districts of Kandahar, said Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor, adding that 19 Taliban forces were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnother attack by the Taliban on a police base in Zabul province killed eight policemen. Asif Tokhi, a police official, said the base, located along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, came under attack late on Wednesday and security was restored only in the following morning. He said three policemen were also wounded in the clashes, which left 12 Taliban militants killed.\n\nThe Taliban have yet to claim the multiple attacks in the south while there has been no confirmation of the casualties among the ranks of the group.\n\nThe renewed attacks by the Taliban militants, which have also inflicted casualties on the US forces, come amid fresh warnings by the group about the need for the US to fully withdraw its forces from Afghanistan after more than a decade and half of occupation.\n\nUS President Donald Trump has resisted repeated requests by the Pentagon to approve the deployment of another 4,000-strong US force to Afghanistan, which the US military says is needed to boost the so-called counter-terrorism operations in the country.\n\nThere soldier", "uri": "711031809", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:50:00Z", "time": "17:50:00", "body": "US soldier killed in operations against militants in eastern Afghanistan\n\nA US National Guard soldier has been killed during an anti-militant operation in eastern Afghanistan.\n\nThe US military said Thursday that the soldier had been killed during a joint operation a day earlier against the Daesh Takfiri terrorist group in the eastern province of Nangarhar.\n\nThe Utah National Guard said in a statement that the battle in the Achin district of Nangarhar had also left several Afghan forces injured, along with seven other National Guardsmen, adding that all those injured were receiving medical treatment.\n\nThe statement did not elaborate on the identity of the slain American soldier and those wounded in the attack, saying details would be released after notifying the victims' families.\n\nThe casualties are the latest in Afghanistan's new campaign against Daesh, a terror group mainly operating in Iraq and Syria which has managed to gain a foothold in the war-torn country.\n\nDaesh mostly recruits disgruntled militants from the Taliban, the most established militant group in Afghanistan which is reorganizing some 16 years after its ouster from power by a US-led invasion.\n\nAfghan authorities said Thursday that a total of three civilians and 15 Afghan policemen were killed in three southern provinces in attacks by the Taliban that took place on Wednesday.\n\nThe civilian casualties were reported in Helmand, where a bomber tried to target a military base. Omar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker was killed in the blast while three other militants on foot were shot dead when guards opened fire on them. He said the explosion also left three Afghan forces injured.\n\nSeven policemen were killed and nine were wounded in two similar attacks by the Taliban on police checkpoints in two districts of Kandahar, said Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor, adding that 19 Taliban forces were killed in the ensuing clashes.\n\nAnother attack by the Taliban on a police base in Zabul province killed eight policemen. Asif Tokhi, a police official, said the base, located along the Zabul-Kandahar highway, came under attack late on Wednesday and security was restored only in the following morning. He said three policemen were also wounded in the clashes, which left 12 Taliban militants killed.\n\nThe Taliban have yet to claim the multiple attacks in the south while there has been no confirmation of the casualties among the ranks of the group.\n\nThe renewed attacks by the Taliban militants, which have also inflicted casualties on the US forces, come amid fresh warnings by the group about the need for the US to fully withdraw its forces from Afghanistan after more than a decade and half of occupation.\n\nUS President Donald Trump has resisted repeated requests by the Pentagon to approve the deployment of another 4,000-strong US force to Afghanistan, which the US military says is needed to boost the so-called counter-terrorism operations in the country.\n\nThere are 8,400 American troops in Afghanistan, Washington claims they are advising and assisting the Afghan military in the fight against the Taliban and Daesh.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": If you'd like to learn more...\n\nThe Afghan Taliban on Tuesday released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war.\n\nIn a long and rambling note in English that was sent to journalists by Zabihullah Mujahid, the Taliban spokesman, the insurgents said Trump has recognized the errors of his predecessors by seeking a review of the U.S. strategy for Afghanistan.\n\nREAD MORE: 140 Afghan soldiers dead after Taliban disguised in army uniforms storm base\n\nHowever, Mujahid said Trump should not hand control of the U.S. Afghan policy to the military but rather announce the withdrawal of U.S. forces -- and not an increase in troops as the administration has planned.\n\nThe 1,600-word note said a U.S. withdrawal would \"truly deliver American troops from harm's way\" and bring about \"an end to an inherited war.\"\n\nThe U.S. now has about 8,400 troops in Afghanistan.\n\nWATCH: Obama announces 8,400 troops will stay in Afghanistan\n\nStory continues below\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\nWhat is evident is that the Afghan government has struggled to halt Taliban advances on its own and is now also battling an Islamic State affiliate that has carved out a foothold mostly in eastern Afghanistan. In its most recent report, the U.S. Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction said the Taliban hold sway in nearly 50 per cent of the country.\n\nThe Taliban letter sought to flatter Trump for initiating the Afghan policy review while warning against handing it to \"warmongering generals.\"\n\nREAD MORE: Russia must be confronted for arming the Taliban, says U.S. general in Afghanistan\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethinking your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" it said, addressing Trump.\n\n\"You must also not hand over the Afghan issue to warmongering generals, but must make a decision where history shall remember you as an advocate of peace.\"\n\nThe letter also offered a long list of complaints against Afghanistan's U.S.-orchestrated unity government and referenced a newly formed coalition of disgruntled warlords formed at a meeting last month in Turkey as an opposition bloc to Afghan President Ashraf Ghani.\n\nWATCH: U.S. defence secretary says 'we are not winning in Afghanistan'\n\nGhani has been under pressure from critics who have described him as divisive and accused him of stoking ethnic rivalries.\n\nThe opposition bloc includes Uzbek warlord and Afghanistan's first vice-president, Rashid Dostum, who has been criticized by the U.S. for human rights abuses and is currently living in Turkey. Atta Mohammed Noor, a Tajik warlord and governor of northern Balkh province and Mohammed Mohaqiq, an ethnic Hazara lawmaker are also in the bloc.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": They mainly serve as trainers and advisers to Afghan forces.\n\nTrump's administration is currently finalising a new policy for Afghanistan almost 16 years after the US invasion to topple the Taliban regime.\n\nAmerican military commanders in Afghanistan have requested thousands of extra boots on the ground to help combat a resurgent Taliban.\n\nDefense Secretary Jim Mattis is believed to be close Sputnik Afghanistan discussed with Afghan political analysts whether it will force the US leader to alter his new, yet-to-be-announced policy for the Asian country.\n\nOn Sunday, the Taliban radical movement released a new open letter to President Donald Trump, calling for a full withdrawal of the foreign forces from Afghanistan, claiming that the ongoing violence in the country has a direct link to the presence of the foreign forces, which it calls \"occupation forces.\"\n\nIt also said that the war in Afghanistan is being used in their own interest and accused the US-led coalition for the destruction of Afghanistan that has turned the country as one of the worst in terms of security, governance, and economy.\n\n\u00a9 AFP 2017/ Thomas WATKINSWhy US Won't Leave Central Asia 'Any Time Soon' and What It is Really After ThereThe Taliban's new letter has been released as the Trump administration is currently reviewing its Afghanistan policy.\n\nSputnik Afghanistan discussed with Afghan political analysts whether it will force the US leader to alter its plans for the Asian country.\n\n\"Afghanistan is currently in the center of attention of world and regional powers - the US, NATO member states, Russia and its allies India and China. However we can't deny that from the economic point of view, the US and other NATO member states are bearing major expenses in our country. They vowed to provide assistance to Afghanistan until 2020,\" political analyst Ruhollah Ahmadzai told Sputnik.\n\nHe further noted that the war in Afghanistan has turned into a big headache for the US and its European allies because their calculations, which they made 17 years ago, have failed.\n\nWith regards to the Taliban's letter to Trump, the political analyst said that it reflects more the will of Pakistan and its intelligence services rather than any desires of the Taliban. Thus this letter does not actually matter to the White House.\n\nRuhollah Ahmadzai also commented on the possible increase of the US contingent in his country.\n\n\u00a9 WikipediaUS' Blackwater Mercenaries 'Will Bring Hatred, Not Peace to Afghanistan'On August 3, US Sen. Lindsey Graham said the United States could turn the tide of the war in Afghanistan with just 3,000-4,000 additional troops and boosted air capacity.\n\nLast week, US Sen. In July, US Defense Secretary James Mattis said the Pentagon was close to completing its policy review for a new strategy in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The suggested increase of the US troops in Afghanistan should become a topic for discussion between the American and Afghan political analysts,\" Ruhollah Ahmadzai told Sputnik.\n\nHe further explained that if the US increases its contingent, it will be the repetition of the bloody events which happened 17 years ago and won't contribute to the fight against terrorism. What the US should really do, he said, is hold Pakistan accountable for its 22-year-long subversive activities in Afghanistan. It should study all the documental evidence of the UN and US intelligence services. Through intermediary of the US, all countries should condemn the criminal activities of Pakistan and isolate this country.\n\nWhen asked if the Taliban is able to overtake Afghanistan once again, the political analyst said that the military and political situation in the country is different from what it was 17 years ago,\n\n\"Our army has become better and stronger, our provinces become more secure. Our army is able to rebuff the attacks of terrorist groups which are being sent from abroad,\" he said.\n\n\u00a9 REUTERS/ Omar SobhaniWhat's Behind Russia's Warning of 'Resorting to Military Force' in Afghanistan?According to political analyst Nasir Torki, the letter to Trump contains nothing new.\n\n\"For 15 years Taliban has been putting forward the same very demands. However we should not dismiss the fact that this movement has recently strengthened militarily and has got new political backers,\" he told Sputnik.\n\nHowever if the Afghan security forces get considerable financial support, he said, they will be able to help the Afghan government to drive from the deadlock of the ongoing war.\n\nMeanwhile, US Department of State spokeswoman Heather Nauert has commented on the letter.\n\n\"What is going on in Afghanistan is a result of the Taliban. We've seen, and there was a report out not that long ago, about the increase in attacks on civilians, which largely included women and children. That is being perpetrated by members of the Taliban,\" she was quoted as saying by Kabul-based Khaama Press news agency.\n\n\u00a9 Sputnik/ Alexandr GraschenkovMystery Aviation in Afghanistan: Whose is it?\"Let's not lose focus that the Taliban is behind many of those attacks, many of the increase in civilian casualties. That undermines the Afghan population and also the Afghan Government as well, so let's not lose focus of that,\" she added.\n\nIn the letter to the US President Taliban however claimed that the ongoing insurgency led by the group \"has a national resistance and is properly administered politically and militarily, insisting that in absence of such an administration the violence could further It did not specify how many forces were wounded.\n\nIslamic State militants have gained a foothold in recent years in Afghanistan, where they have battled U.S.-backed government forces as well as the more established Taliban.\n\nThe ISIS affiliate largely consists of disgruntled former Taliban insurgents, and has clashed with the larger group over leadership and ideology.\n\nElsewhere in Afghanistan, a suicide car bomber killed three civilians while trying to attack an Afghan army base in the southern Helmand province late Wednesday.\n\nOmar Zwak, spokesman for the provincial governor, said the attacker and three other militants approached the base before guards opened fire on them, killing the three who were on foot. Three soldiers were wounded in the blast.\n\nIn the southern Kandahar province, Taliban fighters stormed police checkpoints in two districts late Wednesday, killing seven police and wounding nine others, according to Zia Durani, spokesman for the provincial governor. {"sim": 0.7607843279838562, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9226934", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "tolonews.com", "title": "tolonews.com", "id": "16207"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://www.tolonews.com/sites/default/files/james-mattis.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.tolonews.com/node/58496", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:27:00", "title": "Full Withdrawal From Afghanistan Is An Option: Mattis | TOLOnews", "uri": "709634603", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T07:27:00Z", "time": "07:27:00", "body": "US Defense Secretary said on Monday that \"all options\" remained on the table over a new strategy for Afghanistan and \"full withdrawal\" is also possible.\n\nThe US Defense Secretary James Mattis said at a press conference on Monday that President Donald Trump's administration was \"very, very close\" to finalising its new strategy for Afghanistan but warned it had not been settled yet.\n\n\"The strategic decisions have not been made,\" Mattis said adding that \"all options\" remained on the table for how to approach Afghanistan, and said those options included a full withdrawal as well as a proposal for the use of more contractors to manage the US effort there.\n\nMattis added that all options for a new strategy in Afghanistan, including the use of private security contractors, remain under consideration by Trump.\n\nThe plans could lead to sending an additional 3,000-4,000 US troops to Afghanistan, but the president reportedly has been frustrated by his options in the nearly 16-year-old conflict and has considered firing the US commander in Afghanistan.\n\n\"We're sharpening each one of the options,\" Mattis said. \"You can see the pluses and minuses of each one so that there's no longer any new data you are going to get. Now, just make the decision. There's the options.\"\n\nIn response to a question on whether Trump had confidence in Gen. John Nicholson, the US and NATO commander in Afghanistan, he said: \"He is our commander in the field. He has the confidence of NATO.\"\n\n\"He has the confidence of Afghanistan. He has the confidence of the United States, and the President again is looking at all aspects of our effort over there as he must in his responsibilities as the commander-in-chief,\" he said.\n\nIn the meantime, Zamir Kabulov, special representative of the Russian President in Afghanistan said that the military campaign of the US army in Afghanistan is \"failing\", and as such the US needs to withdraw its contingent from the country.\n\n\"Moscow has never hastened withdrawal of the US troops from Afghanistan. But as far as the US army cannot do anything, let them leave Afghanistan. The American campaign in Afghanistan has failed. Afghanistan can become the world incubator of international terrorism. Actually, it partially is,\" he said in an interview with Izvestiya newspaper.\n\nRussia is however against the replacement of the regular US army with contract soldiers in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The US is in despair; the plan to change the professional soldiers into contract soldiers is nonsense. It will not bring anything good: contract soldiers will simply escape. They conscript them for the money from all over the world. How are they going to fight against the Taliban,\" he added.\n\nNearly 16 years after the US led a coalition to bring down the Taliban, US-led forces and the new Afghan government have struggled to stabilize the country and push back the Taliban.\n\nLast week, US Senator John McCain revealed his own strategy for the United States in Afghanistan because Trump's administration isn't coming up with one, he said.\n\nMcCain's Afghan strategy includes adding more US troops for counter terrorism missions; increasing US air power to assist Afghan forces; and providing the US military with broader authority to target enemy forces including the Taliban, the Haqqani Network, al-Qaeda and Daesh.\n\nMcCain also would have the US military advising Afghan forces at a battalion level.\n\nMcCain wants his country to enter into an agreement with the Afghan government for an enduring US counter-terrorism presence in Afghanistan, and he wants to put more pressure on Pakistan to stop providing sanctuaries to the Taliban and Haqqani Network.\n\nThe White House has been divided between two factions, with the US national security adviser HR McMaster seeking to bolster American troops in Afghanistan, and Trump's chief strategist Steve Bannon opposing additional US forces, according to reports.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", {"sim": 0.7607843279838562, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9286938", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "presstv.ir", "title": "presstv.ir", "id": "9258"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://media.presstv.com/photo/20170815/53e99926-1b64-4880-9eaf-037a4b2519a9.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.presstv.ir/Detail/2017/08/15/531848/Taliban-Zabihullah-Mujahid-Trump-US-Afghanistan-Daesh", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:33:00", "title": "PressTV-Taliban to Trump: Leave Afghanistan", "uri": "709787927", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:33:00Z", "time": "13:33:00", "body": "Taliban 'open letter' to Trump calls on US to leave Afghanistan\n\nThe Taliban militant group has released an \"open letter\" to US President Donald Trump, reiterating their demand for the withdrawal of US forces from Afghanistan after 16 years of war.\n\nIn a long and rambling note that was sent to journalists by Zabihullah Mujahid, the Taliban spokesman, the insurgents said a withdrawal would \"truly deliver American troops from harm's way\" and bring about \"an end to an inherited war.\"\n\nThe 1,600-word note said Trump should not hand control of the US Afghan policy to the military but rather announce the withdrawal of US troops.\n\nThe Taliban spokesman said the current US president has recognized the errors of his predecessors by seeking a review of the US strategy for Afghanistan.\n\nThe United States now has about 8,400 troops in Afghanistan. The Pentagon seeks to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster US counterterrorism operations. Trump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations.\n\nThe Taliban letter, which sought to flatter Trump for initiating the Afghan policy review, also warned against handing it to \"warmongering generals.\"\n\n\"You must also not hand over the Afghan issue to warmongering generals, but must make a decision where history shall remember you as an advocate of peace,\" Taliban's letter said, addressing Trump.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethinking your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" it added.\n\nThe letter also offered a long list of complaints against Afghanistan's US-orchestrated unity government.\n\nIt also referred to a newly formed coalition of disgruntled warlords formed at a meeting last month in Turkey as an opposition bloc to Afghan President Ashraf Ghani.\n\nCritics have described President Ghani as divisive and accused him of stoking ethnic rivalries.\n\nThe opposition bloc includes Uzbek warlord and Afghanistan's first vice president, Rashid Dostum, and Atta Mohammed Noor, a Tajik warlord and governor of the northern province of Balkh.\n\nDostum has been criticized by the US for human rights abuses and is currently living in Turkey.\n\nMohammed Mohaqiq, an ethnic Hazara lawmaker, is also in the bloc.\n\nUS Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction said in its most recent report that the Taliban militants hold sway in nearly 50 percent of the country.\n\nThe war in Afghanistan is the longest in US history with a cost of about $1 trillion. More than 2,400 Americans have died and another 20,000 have been wounded in the country since the invasion in 2001.\n\nUS President Donald Trump has been skeptical about the campaign in Afghanistan. US officials have said that Trump's doubts about the war have led to a delay in completing a new strategy in the war-torn country.\n\nTrump has said in a recent meeting with his national security team that the United States is \"losing\" in Afghanistan.\n\nRead more:\n\nThe Daesh Takfiri terrorist group, which is mainly concentrated in Iraq and Syria, has been sustaining heavy losses in battles with national armies and allied forces in those countries in the past months.\n\nThe Takfiri group emerged in Afghanistan in early 2015 and has claimed responsibility for some deadly attacks in the country.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100, "id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict"}, {"uri": ISIS-K has conducted several deadly attacks throughout the country this year.\n\nWednesday's death is the third U.S. combat fatality this month, following an attack on a NATO convoy in Kandahar province on Aug. 2 that killed two soldiers and wounded four others.\n\nThe military did not specify where the operation was being conducted Wednesday, beyond saying it was in eastern Afghanistan. At least six of the nine combat fatalities so far this year have occurred in eastern Nangarhar province, where troops have been battling ISIS-K in recent months.\n\nIn April, U.S. forces dropped the \"mother of all bombs\" - the largest conventional bomb ever deployed in combat - to destroy a series of Islamic State caves in a mountainous area in that province along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border, where sustained firefights with ISIS militants had taken place and just days after the first U.S. combat death of the year had occurred.\n\nThe U.S. has made it a priority to defeat ISIS-K in Afghanistan this year.\n\nEarlier this week, when the military announced that it had killed a senior leader in the group, Gen. "http://www.breakingnews.ie/world/taliban-send-1600-word-letter-to-donald-trump-urging-us-to-leave-afghanistan-802164.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:43:00", "title": "Taliban send 1,600-word letter to Donald Trump urging US to leave Afghanistan", "uri": "709898637", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:43:00Z", "time": "17:43:00", "body": "The Taliban have released an open letter to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war.\n\nIn a long and rambling note in English that was sent to journalists by Zabihullah Mujahid, the Taliban spokesman, the insurgents said Mr Trump has recognised the errors of his predecessors by seeking a review of the US strategy for Afghanistan.\n\nHowever, Mujahid said Mr Trump should not hand control of the US Afghan policy to the military but rather announce the withdrawal of US forces - and not an increase in troops as the administration has planned.\n\nThe 1,600-word note said a US withdrawal would \"truly deliver American troops from harm's way\" and bring about \"an end to an inherited war\".\n\nThe United States now has about 8,400 troops in Afghanistan.\n\nMr Trump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more troops to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster US counter-terrorism operations.\n\nThe deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilise Afghanistan.\n\nWhat is evident is that the Afghan government has struggled to halt Taliban advances on its own and is now also battling an Islamic State affiliate that has carved out a foothold mostly in eastern Afghanistan.\n\nIn its most recent report, the US Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction said the Taliban hold sway in nearly 50% of the country.\n\nThe Taliban letter sought to flatter Mr Trump for initiating the Afghan policy review while warning against handing it to \"warmongering generals\".\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethinking your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" it said, addressing Mr Trump.\n\n\"You must also not hand over the Afghan issue to warmongering generals, but must make a decision where history shall remember you as an advocate of peace.\"\n\nThe letter also offered a long list of complaints against Afghanistan's US-orchestrated unity government and referenced a newly formed coalition of disgruntled warlords formed at a meeting last month in Turkey as an opposition bloc to Afghan President Ashraf Ghani.\n\nMr Ghani has been under pressure from critics who have described him as divisive and accused him of stoking ethnic rivalries.\n\nThe opposition bloc includes Uzbek warlord and Afghanistan's first vice president, Rashid Dostum, who has been criticised by the US for human rights abuses and is currently living in Turkey.\n\nAP", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues", "wgt": 100, "id": 41, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues"}, {"uri": "710211064", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T08:56:00Z", "time": "08:56:00", "body": "In an open letter dated August 15, the Taliban told US President Donald Trump that the military situation in Afghanistan was \"far worse than you realise\" and sending in more troops would be self-destructive.\n\nThe letter comes following a request by senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, for several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nSpeaking to the Reuters news agency, a senior Taliban official said the rare decision to address Trump directly was timed to coincide with the president's deliberations on the future of US policy in Afghanistan.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taliban said in the lengthy English-language letter.\n\nIt criticised the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying, corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who were providing Washington with \"rosy pictures\" of the military position.\n\nAccording to Reuters, the Taliban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, has waged an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led invasion after the September 11 attacks in 2001.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realise!\" the letter said, arguing that the only thing preventing the Taliban from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nMeanwhile, US Defence Secretary Jim Mattis told reporters on August 14 that the Trump administration was \"very, very close\" to a decision on Afghanistan, adding that all options were on the table. {"sim": 0.7411764860153198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9363685", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "globalsecurity.org", "title": "GlobalSecurity.org", "id": "5033"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": null, "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2017/08/mil-170815-presstv04.htm", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "21:52:00", "title": "Taliban 'open letter' to Trump calls on US to leave Afghanistan", "uri": "709994544", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T21:52:00Z", "time": "21:52:00", "body": "The Taliban militant group has released an \"open letter\" to US President Donald Trump, reiterating their demand for the withdrawal of US forces from Afghanistan after 16 years of war.\n\nIn a long and rambling note that was sent to journalists by Zabihullah Mujahid, the Taliban spokesman, the insurgents said a withdrawal would \"truly deliver American troops from harm's way\" and bring about \"an end to an inherited war.\"\n\nThe 1,600-word note said Trump should not hand control of the US Afghan policy to the military but rather announce the withdrawal of US troops.\n\nThe Taliban spokesman said the current US president has recognized the errors of his predecessors by seeking a review of the US strategy for Afghanistan.\n\nThe United States now has about 8,400 troops in Afghanistan. The Pentagon seeks to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster US counterterrorism operations. Trump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations.\n\nThe Taliban letter, which sought to flatter Trump for initiating the Afghan policy review, also warned against handing it to \"warmongering generals.\"\n\n\"You must also not hand over the Afghan issue to warmongering generals, but must make a decision where history shall remember you as an advocate of peace,\" Taliban's letter said, addressing Trump.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethinking your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" it added.\n\nThe letter also offered a long list of complaints against Afghanistan's US-orchestrated unity government.\n\nIt also referred to a newly formed coalition of disgruntled warlords formed at a meeting last month in Turkey as an opposition bloc to Afghan President Ashraf Ghani.\n\nCritics have described President Ghani as divisive and accused him of stoking ethnic rivalries.\n\nThe opposition bloc includes Uzbek warlord and Afghanistan's first vice president, Rashid Dostum, and Atta Mohammed Noor, a Tajik warlord and governor of the northern province of Balkh.\n\nDostum has been criticized by the US for human rights abuses and is currently living in Turkey.\n\nMohammed Mohaqiq, an ethnic Hazara lawmaker, is also in the bloc.\n\nUS Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction said in its most recent report that the Taliban militants hold sway in nearly 50 percent of the country.\n\nThe war in Afghanistan is the longest in US history with a cost of about $1 trillion. More than 2,400 Americans have died and another 20,000 have been wounded in the country since the invasion in 2001.\n\nUS President Donald Trump has been skeptical about the campaign in Afghanistan. US officials have said that Trump's doubts about the war have led to a delay in completing a new strategy in the war-torn country.\n\nTrump has said in a recent meeting with his national security team that the United States is \"losing\" in Afghanistan.\n\nThe Daesh Takfiri terrorist group, which is mainly concentrated in Iraq and Syria, has been sustaining heavy losses in battles with national armies and allied forces in those countries in the past months.\n\nThe Takfiri group emerged in Afghanistan in early 2015 and has claimed responsibility for some deadly attacks in the country.", {"sim": 0.7372549176216125, "details": {"liCnt": 14}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9260127", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "aljazeera.com", "title": "aljazeera.com", "id": "3408"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://www.aljazeera.com/mritems/Images/2017/7/26/cbeb5c604a5748adbacaeffc4899cdf5_18.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/08/taliban-open-letter-trump-urges-leave-afghan-170815052154246.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:59:00", "title": "Taliban 'open letter' to Trump urges US to leave Afghan", "uri": "709717914", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T10:59:00Z", "time": "10:59:00", "body": "Armed group presses US president for a complete withdrawal to save the lives of Americans and Afghans in an open letter.\n\nThe Taliban called on President Donald Trump on Tuesday to review the strategy for the war in Afghanistan and to hold peaceful dialogue directly with Afghans instead of engaging \"corrupt\" politicians.\n\nWritten in a tone of negotiation, the Taliban asked Trump to study the \"historical mistakes\" of his predecessors and to withdraw troops from Afghanistan completely.\n\nThe letter urged the US to interact with Afghans \"generously\" instead of imposing war.\n\n\"It seems to be a historical mistake on part of the previous administrations to have dispatched American youth for the slaughter of Afghans. However, as a responsible American president, you need to study the mistakes of your predecessors and prevent death and injury to American forces in Afghanistan,\" it said.\n\nAfghanistan was invaded by the United States in 2001 and has become Washington's longest military intervention since Vietnam. It has also been the costliest with more than $100bn spent.\n\n\"American youth are not born to be killed in the deserts and mountains of Afghanistan in order to establish the writ of thieves and corrupt officials and neither would their parents approve of them killing civilians in Afghanistan,\" the letter said.\n\nThe Taliban also accused Afghan politicians and generals of protracting the war and occupation for personal gain.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges, but instead you must act responsibly as the fate of many Americans and Afghans alike is tied to this issue.\"\n\nREAD MORE: SIGAR questions millions spent in Afghanistan\n\nIn a press conference on Monday, US Defense Secretary James Mattis said all options for Afghanistan remained on the table, and a full withdrawal of troops is one of them.\n\nTrump has yet to announce a strategy for Afghanistan, but Mattis said one is \"very, very close\".\n\nPossible plans include sending thousands more troops into the nearly 16-year conflict, or taking the opposite tack and pulling out, leaving private military contractors to help the Afghans oversee the fragile security situation.\n\nErik Prince, founder of the private security company Blackwater, has offered his private military force for Afghanistan, proposing a two-year plan in which American troops - aside from a handful of special forces - would be replaced by his army of about 5,500 contractors who would train Afghan soldiers and join them in the fight against the Taliban.\n\nHowever, the Taliban said privatising the war effort would be a grave mistake.\n\nIf the war can't be won with \"professional US and NATO troops ... you shall never be able to win it with mercenaries, notorious contractor firms, and immoral stooges\", the Taliban letter said.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.7372549176216125, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9272969", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.co.uk", "title": "International Business Times UK", "id": "713"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://d.ibtimes.co.uk/en/full/1608427/afghanistan-taliban-attack.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 395, "textEnd": 404, "date": "2017-08-15", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/afghan-taliban-writes-open-letter-president-donald-trump-urging-total-withdrawal-1635098", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:16:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban writes open letter to President Donald Trump urging total withdrawal", "uri": "709752099", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T12:16:00Z", "time": "12:16:00", "body": "The Islamist group's letter comes as the US reassesses its Afghan policy.\n\nEven as the administration of US President Donald Trump is reviewing its Afghan policy, the Taliban has written an open letter to Trump urging full withdrawal of American forces from the conflict-torn country. The Islamist group has stepped up its insurgency in recent months capturing vast swathes of territory.\n\nDated 15 August and written in English, the letter was circulated to journalists through regular jihadist channels by Taliban spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid. The group demanded that US forces leave the country altogether after 16 years of bloody conflict instead of increasing the number of troops.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economic might,\" the Taliban said in its 1,600-word letter which adopted a negotiating tone. It called on Trump to \"generously\" hold a dialogue with the Afghans rather than choosing war.\n\n\"It seems to be a historical mistake on part of the previous administrations to have dispatched American youth for the slaughter of Afghans. However, as a responsible American president, you need to study the mistakes of your predecessors and prevent death and injury to American forces in Afghanistan,\" added the open letter.\n\nWith more than $100bn spent since the US' first invasion in 2001, Afghanistan has been regarded as Washington's costliest conflict so far. Attributing the ongoing violence in Afghanistan to the \"occupying forces\" of the US, the Taliban said US presence only fuels the fighting in the country.\n\n\"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges, but instead you must act responsibly as the fate of many Americans and Afghans alike is tied to this issue,\" the Taliban said.\n\nThe letter comes a day after US Defence Secretary James Mattis said the Trump administration was considering all options on Afghanistan. close\".\n\nPossible plans include sending thousands more troops into the nearly 16-year conflict, or taking the opposite tack and pulling out, leaving private military contractors to help the Afghans {"sim": 0.729411780834198, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9251986", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "timescolonist.com", "title": "Times Colonist", "id": "1066"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Pakistan"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Islamabad"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://www.timescolonist.com/polopoly_fs/1.978487.1398105534!/fileImage/httpImage/tc-facebook-logo-156x154.png", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.timescolonist.com/taliban-open-letter-to-trump-urges-us-to-leave-afghanistan-1.21881724", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:11:00", "title": "Taliban 'open letter' to Trump urges US to leave Afghanistan", "uri": "709697790", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T10:11:00Z", "time": "10:11:00", "body": "ISLAMABAD -- The Afghan Taliban on Tuesday released an \"open letter\" to President Donald Trump, reiterating their calls for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Afghanistan after 16 years of war.\n\nIn a long and rambling note in English that was sent to journalists by Zabihullah Mujahid, the Taliban spokesman, the insurgents said Trump has recognized the errors of his predecessors by seeking a review of the U.S. strategy for Afghanistan.\n\nHowever, Mujahid said Trump should not hand control of the U.S. Afghan policy to the military but rather announce the withdrawal of U.S. forces -- and not an increase in troops as the administration has planned.\n\nThe 1,600-word note said a U.S. withdrawal would \"truly deliver American troops from harm's way\" and bring about \"an end to an inherited war.\"\n\nThe United States now has about 8,400 troops in Afghanistan.\n\nTrump has so far resisted the Pentagon's recommendations to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster U.S. counterterrorism operations. The deployment has been held up amid broader strategy questions, including how to engage regional powers in an effort to stabilize Afghanistan.\n\nWhat is evident is that the Afghan government has struggled to halt Taliban advances on its own and is now also battling an Islamic State affiliate that has carved out a foothold mostly in eastern Afghanistan. In its most recent report, the U.S. Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction said the Taliban hold sway in nearly 50 per cent of the country.\n\nThe Taliban letter sought to flatter Trump for initiating the Afghan policy review while warning against handing it to \"warmongering generals.\"\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethinking your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" it said, addressing Trump. \"You must also not hand over the Afghan issue to warmongering generals, but must make a decision where history shall remember you as an advocate of peace.\"\n\nThe letter also offered a long list of complaints against Afghanistan's U.S.-orchestrated unity government and referenced a newly formed coalition of disgruntled warlords formed at a meeting last month in Turkey as an opposition bloc to Afghan President Ashraf Ghani.\n\nGhani has been under pressure from critics who have described him as divisive and accused him of stoking ethnic rivalries.\n\nThe opposition bloc includes Uzbek warlord and Afghanistan's first vice-president, Rashid Dostum, who has been criticized by the U.S. for human rights abuses and is currently living in Turkey. Atta Mohammed Noor, a Tajik warlord and governor of northern Balkh province and Mohammed Mohaqiq, an ethnic Hazara lawmaker are also in the bloc.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri":
