{"sim": 0.6470588445663452, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9380926", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "azcentral.com", "title": "az central", "id": "321"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://www.gannett-cdn.com/GDContent/applogos/azcentral.png", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.azcentral.com/story/opinion/op-ed/robertrobb/2017/08/15/john-mccain-wrong-get-out-afghanistan/570038001/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:30:00", "title": "Robb: McCain is wrong. We need to get out of Afghanistan", "uri": "710041594", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T00:30:00Z", "time": "00:30:00", "body": "Skip in Skipx\n\nEmbed\n\nx\n\nShare\n\nCLOSE\n\nPresident Trump is reportedly worried we're losing the Afghanistan war. But tensions in the White House have made it hard to settle on a war strategy. Video provided by Newsy Newslook\n\nRobert Robb: After 16 years, $700 billion and 22,000 casualties, it's time to let Afghanistan find its own course.CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE\n\nThe Pentagon is reportedly having trouble convincing President Donald Trump to increase troop levels in Afghanistan. A promised new Afghanistan strategy has been delayed.\n\nArizona Sen. John McCain has stepped into the breach. He has drafted his own Afghanistan strategy that he plans to offer as an amendment to the defense funding authorization bill, soon to be considered by the U.S. Senate.\n\nThis is, at best, a borderline constitutionally appropriate move. The Constitution is clear that, whereas Congress authorizes war, the president decides how to conduct it.\n\nMcCain has framed his strategy as an expression of the sense of Congress. So, it wouldn't purport to be binding. But it still has at least the flavor of a usurpation of the president's prerogative as commander in chief.\n\nMcCain wants more troops and more aid\n\nNevertheless, the McCain Afghanistan strategy would be worth examination by Trump. It's a more candid explication of the road to a deeper and even longer engagement in the country than he is likely to get from the military brass' incrementalist proposals. It should stiffen Trump's skepticism about heading down that road.\n\nMcCain would vigorously contest this characterization, but his strategy is basically to return Afghanistan to an American protectorate.\n\nMORE: House weighs plan to privatize war in Afghanistan\n\nMore American troops would be sent. American soldiers would be embedded again with Afghanistan combat troops. U.S. air cover would be substantially increased.\n\nU.S. aid to Afghanistan would be boosted. It would be tied to Afghanistan hitting benchmarks on good governance, such as cracking down on corruption, agreed to with the U.S. government.\n\nMcCain's amendment doesn't specify how many additional troops would be required, how much it would cost, or how long the American protectorate would last.\n\nHis approach will be slow and costly\n\nBut the McCain strategy can't be implemented on the cheap or quickly bring success. Unlike other neoconservative hawks, McCain, to his credit, has always been candid about this.\n\nIn 2009, in a speech to the American Enterprise Institute about how to win the Afghanistan war, McCain said: \"The scale of resources required to prevail will be enormous, and the timetable will be measured in years, not months.\"\n\nHis amendment calls for \"an enduring United States counterterrorism presence in Afghanistan\" and \"providing sustained support to the Afghan National Security and Defense Forces.\"\n\nNow, it is true that the United States has never committed to the level of involvement in Afghanistan McCain supports. So, it cannot be said that his approach has been tried and failed.\n\nBut what we have committed, and the results produced, raises grave doubts that doing even more will produce security gains for the United States commensurate with the massive investment required.\n\nWe've spent a lot with little to show for it\n\nThe United States toppled the Taliban with minimal effort and expense. Basically, we just tipped the balance in a pre-existing low-grade civil war against it. There was no U.S. ground invasion. We mostly just provided the opposition some money and intelligence.\n\nWe have since spent a fortune trying to keep the Taliban from coming back and to establish a functioning Afghanistan government, without much to show for it.\n\nTotal expenditures in Afghanistan have been more than $700 billion. Of that, nearly $70 billion has gone to Afghan security forces and another $45 billion for various humanitarian and reconstruction projects.\n\nThe toll has been more than money. Over 2,000 U.S. soldiers have been killed in the war, and nearly 20,000 wounded.\n\nPrevention isn't worth the cure\n\nDespite all that, Afghanistan is a mess. The writ of the government extends to maybe 60 percent of the country. Transparency International ranks Afghanistan as the seventh most corrupt country in the world. The World Bank ranks it near the bottom in the ease of doing business.\n\nAfter 16 years, over $700 billion, and some 22,000 casualties, it's time to let Afghanistan find its own course.\n\nIf some jihadist safe zones that threaten the United States emerge, we can take targeted action to nullify the threat, as we did to initially chase out the Taliban.\n\nIn this case, an ounce of prevention, in terms of keeping the Taliban at bay, isn't worth a pound of cure. If anything, in Afghanistan, the ratio has been the reverse.\n\nReach Robb at robert.robb@arizonarepublic.com.\n\nMORE FROM ROBB:\n\nThe judge, not the corrections officer, was out of line\n\nLet's clarify what happened to Joe Arpaio\n\nCONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORERead or Share this story: http://azc.cc/2x2x4MU", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": All but one resulted from hostile enemy action, according to Defense Department data. It comes, too, as America's longest war nears the start of its 17th year, and the Trump administration remains without a clear strategy.\n\nThe ISIS affiliate in Afghanistan, a group known as ISIS Khorasan, or ISIS-K, is entrenched along the county's mountainous border. Backed by U.S. troops and firepower, Afghan commando units have aggressively pursued its fighters for many months and shown some progress in disrupting their activity.\n\nAmerican and Afghan troops launched Operation Hamza in early March. The following month, U.S. forces carried out a massive airstrike on an ISIS tunnel complex in Nangarhar's Achin district, killing upward of 100 militants. At the time, U.S. officials estimated that between 400 and 700 ISIS-K militants remained in Afghanistan.\n\nISIS-K is an offshoot of the terror group's core network in Iraq and Syria, receiving tactical guidance and financial support from outside Afghanistan but few additional fighters.\n\nAbout 14,000 U.S. and NATO troops remain in Afghanistan. With backing from the Pentagon, the war's top commander, Gen. John Nicholson, wants to grow his force by around 4,000 American troops, with a match from other NATO countries.\n\nThe White House has not committed to that plan, though. Some advisers have suggested that contractors could gradually assume the training and advisory mission there, allowing U.S troops to come home.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.6352941393852234, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368636", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9835818", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "title": "The Express Tribune", "id": "1929"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://c.tribune.com.pk/2017/08/1484576-ussoldiersafghanistanreuters-1503036708-261-640x480.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 1483, "textEnd": 1489, "date": "2017-08-02", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2976, "textEnd": 2982, "date": "-05-31", "amb": false}], "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/1484576/guardian-angel-need-advisers-afghanistan-drives-call-troops/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "06:37:00", "title": "'Guardian angel' need for advisers in Afghanistan drives call for more troops", "uri": "711292608", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T06:37:00Z", "time": "06:37:00", "body": "KABUL: Navigating a chaotic maze of cars and people, the convoy of British army armored vehicles weaves slowly through Kabul. The job of about a dozen soldiers is to protect just two international advisers on their way to meet Afghan soldiers.\n\nWhile every mission varies, for every adviser deployed in Afghanistan as part of a NATO-led multinational force, many more soldiers are tasked with providing security and support.\n\nThe minimum security requirements mean that providing even just a few thousand advisers for Afghan security forces is a monumental task that, if continued, will keep many thousands more international troops and contractors facing daily threats.\n\nNew US strategy for Afghanistan\n\nThat calculus will factor into arguments put before US President Donald Trump on Friday as he and advisers meet ahead of a long-awaited decision on strategy and troop levels for the United States' longest war.\n\nFewer than 25 percent of coalition troops in Afghanistan are dedicated advisers - with the rest either in a security, support or a combined role.\n\nThe need to balance the force with more advisers is a driving factor behind the military's request for more troops, which has met with scepticism in Washington, where Trump was elected on a platform of reducing American commitments overseas.\n\nProviding security and support for the advising mission can be a deceptively dangerous job, with hours of quiet routine that can be broken by deadly violence at any moment.\n\nOn Aug. 2, two American soldiers were killed by a suicide car bomb as they were providing security for a convoy in the southern province of Kandahar.\n\nThe next day, a Georgian soldier was killed when a coalition convoy was attacked by a suicide bomber in Kabul.\n\nAnd just two days after that, Romanian soldiers providing security for advisers in Kandahar were forced to shoot and kill an Afghan policeman who attacked the international troops.\n\nFor the soldiers of the British army's Royal Irish Regiment in Kabul, this \"taxi and bodyguard service\" is a far cry from their last deployment to Afghanistan when they battled militants in Helmand province in 2011.\n\n\"We're there in the background if anything happens,\" said ranger Riley Tolliday, describing his job as a \"guardian angel\" escorting advisers to meetings around the Afghan capital.\n\nAfter months of relative calm, since April the Royal Irish Regiment has deployed a \"quick reaction force\" to at least three attacks in the city, said Major Paul Martin, a company commander.\n\nIn April, the regiment's soldiers were deployed to mediate a dispute that arose after a vehicle carrying foreign troops was involved in a traffic accident and was fired upon by Afghan police.\n\nAfghanistan's plans to fly shipments to India bypassing Pakistan go awry\n\nIn early May, the soldiers escorted the disabled vehicles of an US military convoy that had been struck by a suicide bomber, killing eight Afghan bystanders and wounding three Americans.\n\nAnd on May 31, they responded to the scene of a massive truck bomb that detonated in the center of Kabul, killing at least 92 people.\n\nThe British soldiers helped secure the scene and then evacuated casualties from the German embassy, which was heavily damaged.\n\nEven at the height of the international military mission in Afghanistan, a large proportion of troops was involved behind the scenes providing security and other support for the main mission.\n\nOf the 12,447 troops from 39 countries that make up the NATO-led Resolute Support mission, about 2,865 are classified as advisers, according to numbers provided by the coalition.\n\nAnother 7,766 are considered \"enablers\", which can range from logistics and security troops to fighter aircraft pilots.\n\nAnd, finally, 1,816 are deployed as \"command and control\".\n\nAmong the enablers plus command-and-control troops, many also have part-time roles advising Afghan counterparts, but the numbers reveal the massive number of supporting troops needed to field even a limited advising mission.\n\nAmong the 23,500 private contractors also employed by the US military in Afghanistan, only 800 are classified as trainers, according to the Pentagon.\n\nErik Prince, the high-profile founder of the private security firm Blackwater, has proposed using contractors to take over all of the foreign mission in Afghanistan.\n\nWhile the US military has used contractors to buttress the force in Afghanistan, including using private guards for security around some bases, officials say they hope to reduce overall reliance on contractors by deploying more troops.\n\nThe command in Kabul is now waiting on the stalled request for thousands more American troops, which they hope will allow them to deploy more soldiers dedicated to working with the Afghans, but also a \"significant\" number to provide more security, said one senior military official.\n\nIslamabad tells Kabul it's willing to go an extra mile\n\nSecurity services have seen a recent increase in demand as advisers try to reach more Afghan units, Martin said.\n\n\"We're able to fulfill about 80 percent of the requests we receive.\"\n\nThe troops tasked with escorting the advisers on their missions have to not only provide protection from potential militants, but also from so-called insider attacks by members of the Afghan security forces, who have occasionally turned on their foreign allies.", "date": Cody Haas/Marine Corps\n\nA U.S. service member was killed Wednesday during operations in Afghanistan, the Defense Department announced.\n\nThe service member, who wasn't identified, \"died as a result of wounds suffered,\" and an unspecified number of U.S. and Afghan forces were also injured during the operation in the eastern part of the country, according to a statement from U.S. Forces-Afghanistan in Kabul.\n\nThe wounded personnel were medically evacuated from the scene for treatment, it states. {"sim": 0.6313725709915161, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9659291", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "tasnimnews.com", "title": "\u0648\u06a9\u0627\u0644\u0629 \u062a\u0633\u0646\u06cc\u0645 \u0627\u0644\u062f\u0648\u0644\u06cc\u0629 \u0644\u0644\u0623\u0646\u0628\u0627\u0621", "id": "5289"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Kabul"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://newsmedia.tasnimnews.com/Tasnim/Uploaded/Image/1396/05/23/1396052314154442611646964.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "http://www.tasnimnews.com/en/news/2017/08/17/1494356/genocide-not-a-taliban-war-strategy-former-afghan-official", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "10:06:00", "title": "Genocide Not A Taliban War Strategy: Former Afghan Official", "uri": "710810056", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:06:00Z", "time": "10:06:00", "body": "KABUL (Tasnim) - The leader of Afghanistan's Peace Party said mass killing of innocent people over religious differences is not part of the Taliban's war strategy.\n\nLieutenant General Shahnawaz Tanai, a former chief of Afghanistan army, hailed what he called the Taliban's efforts to avoid killing innocent people over their religious beliefs.\n\nHe told Tasnim if all foreign troops withdraw from the South Asian country, the militant group would start holding direct peace talks with the government.\n\nThe Taliban, who ruled the country before being ousted by a US-led invasion in late 2001, have renewed armed insurgency, launching attacks on Afghan military forces.\n\nThe United States now has about 8,400 troops in Afghanistan. The Pentagon seeks to send almost 4,000 more to expand training of Afghan military forces and bolster US counterterrorism operations.\n\nThe US is seeking to reinforce the Daesh (ISIL or ISIS) terror group in Afghanistan to contain the Taliban and hamper any potential peace talks in the country, Tanai said.\n\n\"Daesh is a phenomenon created by the US in order to keep fanning the flame of war in Afghanistan,\" he went on to say.\n\nEarlier, Afghan Taliban Spokesman Zabihullah Mujahid had rejected reports that the group has recently killed dozens of Shiite civilians in a remote village north of Afghanistan as rumors spread by the US and Afghan governments.\n\nAccording to some international media outlets, some 60 people, including women and children, were killed during an attack by militants on Mirza Olang village last Sunday. A number of Afghan security forces were also among the dead.\n\nThe militants set fire to several mosques, torched at least 30 houses, beheaded a number of villagers and shot dozens of others dead, the reports said.\n\nBack in late June, Mujahid had said that the presence of Daesh forces in Afghanistan was limited to a small area in the east and they were living in a dire situation near the border.\n\nNo Daesh fighters are present in other areas of Afghanistan, and the Taliban will not allow such presence, he stressed at the time.", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.6313725709915161, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368636", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-17", "id": "9767428", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "reuters.com", "title": "Reuters", "id": "8"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": null, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1527, "textEnd": 1541, "date": "2001-09-11", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-afghanistan-blast-idUSKCN1AX2HT", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "19:58:00", "title": "U.S. soldier killed in Afghan blast, 20 U.S., Afghan troops wounded", "uri": "711086414", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T19:58:00Z", "time": "19:58:00", "body": "BAGRAM AIRFIELD, Afghanistan (Reuters) - One U.S. soldier was killed and around 20 U.S. and Afghan troops were wounded during a push against Islamic State fighters in Afghanistan, officials said on Thursday, as Washington wrestled with a months-long debate about the 16-year-old war.\n\nThe incident late on Wednesday in Nangarhar province came as several Pentagon officials visited Afghanistan, including Air Force Secretary Heather Wilson and the top generals of the Army and Air Force.\n\nAs the sun pounded down on Bagram Airfield, Wilson, the generals and scores of U.S. troops joined a solemn ceremony to mark the moment the flag-draped coffin carrying the fallen soldier was loaded onto a flight back toward the United States. Some of the troops quietly wept.\n\nFew details about the blast were available, including a firm number of U.S. wounded or the name of the soldier who was killed. One U.S. official said most of the injured American troops had already been released from medical care.\n\nTwo officials said the U.S. and Afghan forces were hit by an explosion inside a building in Nangarhar. They did not say what caused the explosion.\n\nFor Wilson, a former congresswoman who took over the Air Force's top civilian job three months ago, the ceremony was an unexpected part of her reintroduction to the Afghan war.\n\nWith the latest death, 10 U.S. troops have been killed in Afghanistan this year, according to the U.S. military. Nearly 2,400 American troops have been killed since the war began in response to al Qaeda's Sept. 11, 2001, attacks in the United States.\n\nThe incident was a reminder of the high stakes as U.S. President Donald Trump considers requests from the top commander in Afghanistan for thousands more troops beyond the roughly 8,400 who are already here.\n\nThe goal would be to help Afghan forces break a stalemate against Taliban insurgents and, at the same time, prevent rival Islamic State fighters from expanding here as their territory shrinks in Syria and Iraq.\n\nU.S. intelligence agencies have assessed that conditions in Afghanistan will almost certainly deteriorate through next year, even with a modest increase in military assistance from America and its allies.\n\nTrump, Vice President Mike Pence and his national security team are scheduled to discuss Afghan war strategy and regional policy guiding it at a meeting at Camp David on Friday.\n\nWilson and Air Force Chief of Staff General David Goldfein declined to wade into the policy debate about Afghanistan. But, Wilson said, \"Nothing has changed or is likely to change with respect to America's determination to go after terrorists wherever they may be.\"", "date": "2017-08-17", "categories": [{"uri": {"sim": 0.6274510025978088, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368636", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9825048", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "title": "The Express Tribune", "id": "1929"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://c.tribune.com.pk/2017/08/1484133-MuhammadAliEhsanNew-1502987331-576-640x480.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 5459, "textEnd": 5467, "date": "2014-12-", "amb": false}], "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/1484133/afghan-endgame-military-action-political-activism/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:01:00", "title": "Afghan endgame  --  military action or political activism?", "uri": "711255359", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T05:01:00Z", "time": "05:01:00", "body": "The writer is a retired lieutenant colonel of the Pakistan Army and a PhD in civil-military relations\n\n'Don't send more American forces to Afghanistan,' says an open letter addressed to US President Donald Trump published by the Afghan Taliban. The letter suggests the US president should adopt a 'strategy of complete withdrawal from Afghanistan instead of a troop surge'. What does this mean for future of Afghanistan? Will the Trump administration heed the Taliban's suggestion? In the overall cost-benefit analysis of this long fought stalemated war, I think it should.\n\nThe big question that has been asked by the strategists for over a decade and a half now is -- what would yield a stable Afghanistan? Post-9/11 the stability of the world has been associated with the stability of Afghanistan -- billions of dollars have been spent in a stalemated warfare there to convert it into a stable and peaceful state that may eventually become inhospitable to terrorists.\n\nThe attainment of this goal has so far eluded the Americans and their many military and political strategists who tried their luck unsuccessfully -- the latest to that list now would be the Trump administration which is soon going to reveal and unfold its new Afghan policy. How different would it be from the one proffered by Obama, Bush or Clinton?\n\nPresident Obama's administration went all out to execute a deep surge strategy in Afghanistan thus raising the cost of the Afghan war there by spending $100 billion a year on maintaining a troop surge of over 100,000. Two of America's best generals -- General Stanley McChrystal and General David Petraeus -- executed the best possible military doctrine that could be executed in an irregular warfare implementing counterinsurgency operations and through it focused on 'winning hearts and minds' in a political and military strategy that had a clear and an unambiguous aim of 'clearing, holding and building' Afghanistan. But the efforts proved insufficient to turn the tide.\n\nSeen in hindsight the United States employed counterterrorism as its core strategy in Afghanistan -- executing air strikes, special operations raids which didn't have a lasting impact. The counterinsurgency strategy was only introduced and implemented in 2010. Even the US presence in the Taliban stronghold districts like Helmand and Kandahar was negligible and these districts were secured with military presence only after the beginning of the counterinsurgency operations in 2010.\n\nOne of the fatal mistakes made in Afghanistan has been the American assumption that only military actions will contribute to an overall strategic win. Military actions, as is historically proven, only create suitable conditions and an environment for a political solution. Was not initiating 'political activism' more important than conducting military operations in Afghanistan? It seems that American political and military strategy in Afghanistan has been marred by a lack of ability to define a priority -- was it good governance or was it defeating the Taliban? Or, was it both with the result that in the end America ended up achieving neither. If it was assumed that good governance will follow Taliban's defeat than neither have the Taliban been defeated nor has the governance in Afghanistan improved. Today as the Trump administration's new policy in Afghanistan is eagerly awaited one thing seems certain -- Afghanistan may slide back into a full-scale civil war if Washington stops providing serious and sustainable help to it.\n\nSince the time they have been ousted from the government, the Taliban have been fighting a violent war with the aim of seeking back, if not all than some, share of power in Afghanistan. Had the early American intention been to seek a deal with Taliban's rather than try to drone and bomb their leadership to defeat the political and strategic environment in Afghan war today may have been entirely different.\n\nFighting a guerrilla war, the Taliban always had time on their side. Witnessing the lack of American willingness to withdraw their forces from Afghanistan and the continuity of American military goal of obliterating the Taliban leadership through drone strikes the Taliban preferred to wait out the Americans rather than concede to the their offers of dialogue that they considered non serious.\n\nAt the height of the troop surge and with the military presence that the Americans maintained in Afghanistan pushing out the terrorists should not have been their most sought after goal -- 'getting rid of the bad guys and the post-war peace will take care of itself' was an American assumption that never materialised.\n\nUtilising the space and time to build up a corruption-free and legitimate Afghan government could have been the other important goal. Ignoring the making and creation of a political state of Afghanistan was a mistake. Improving civil services, Afghan justice system, doing everything to allow the rule of law to take root by improving the political system and making the executive accountable were very much achievable targets. Former Afghan president Hamid Karzai was considered by many as nothing more than a mayor of Kabul yet the Americans did little to change this equation and do anything to extend his authority. Max Boot, who is a senior fellow for national security studies at the Council of Foreign Relations, made a very sound observation when writing a piece for Foreign Affairs magazine (Nov/Dec 2014) -- 'More Small Wars -- Counterinsurgency is here to stay', he mentioned that the 'State Department and other government agencies could never provide enough skilled personnel in Afghanistan in such areas as governance and economic development to complement the military's efforts; soldiers wound up filling many of the jobs.'\n\nIn hindsight when one looks at the amount of money that the Americans spent and poured into Afghanistan, it is not only the Americans who failed but actually the Afghans themselves as well. Lack of national reconciliation and lack of effective government only added to the choices that many tribes in Afghanistan made to side with the nongovernmental actors such as the Taliban rather than siding with an unpopular, non-delivering and dysfunctional government. If the Americans wanted to project themselves as the protectors of the Afghan society, the people of Afghanistan never accepted that and when the Afghan government like the one of Karzai was as corrupt as it was Afghans only looked at Americans as supporting a government that was corrupt and not people-friendly. Afghanistan didn't need just military action it needed huge Afghan governmental strides in social, political and economic reform -- that never came.\n\nShowcasing a well-financed and well-resourced 'winning political and military plan' why did America fail in Afghanistan?\n\nA large part of the American excuse for this failure is put on Pakistan's shoulders. The US describes the Afghan insurgency as made in Pakistan. In the 'slow motion version' of its defeat that the world has witnessed, Pakistan also had a share of its losses and contrary to how the world looks at the violence being exported from Pakistan to Afghanistan -- instead violence in its worst forms has continuously visited and entered Pakistan from the Afghan border.\n\nThe movement and the organisation that the world recognised as the Taliban has over the years evolved and now converted from being a unilateral, independent monolithic actor to a 'difficult to keep united' and fragmented alliance of many factions. Today very few Taliban fighters reside on the Pakistani side of the border; military action against them has pushed them to the Afghan side.\n\nTo summarise the American military intervention in Afghanistan, it would not be wrong to say that they have been fighting to sustain themselves rather than to achieve their mission and the world may witness a similar military disaster if the Trump administration does not learn lessons from a hard-fought Afghan war in which it hopped from executing one strategy to another. The new Afghan policy must have a well-defined political component that should extend a legal status to the Taliban as a political party thus providing them space for political participation. Else there would be no end to the war in Afghanistan and war in the final analysis war in Afghanistan will continue to remain a contest in stamina between these opposing forces.", "date": {"sim": 0.6039215922355652, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368636", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9809363", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "reuters.com", "title": "Reuters", "id": "8"}, "location": {"country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Kabul"}}, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://s2.reutersmedia.net/resources/r/?m=02&d=20170818&t=2&i=1197585435&w=&fh=545px&fw=&ll=&pl=&sq=&r=LYNXNPED7H044", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 1463, "textEnd": 1469, "date": "2017-08-02", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 2884, "textEnd": 2890, "date": "-05-31", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.reuters.com/article/us-afghanistan-advisers-idUSKCN1AY06C", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:15:00", "title": "'Guardian angel' need for advisers in Afghanistan drives call for more troops", "uri": "711209864", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T02:15:00Z", "time": "02:15:00", "body": "KABUL (Reuters) - Navigating a chaotic maze of cars and people, the convoy of British army armored vehicles weaves slowly through Kabul. The job of about a dozen soldiers is to protect just two international advisers on their way to meet Afghan soldiers.\n\nWhile every mission varies, for every adviser deployed in Afghanistan as part of a NATO-led multinational force, many more soldiers are tasked with providing security and support.\n\nThe minimum security requirements mean that providing even just a few thousand advisers for Afghan security forces is a monumental task that, if continued, will keep many thousands more international troops and contractors facing daily threats.\n\nThat calculus will factor into arguments put before U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday as he and advisers meet ahead of a long-awaited decision on strategy and troop levels for the United States' longest war.\n\nFewer than 25 percent of coalition troops in Afghanistan are dedicated advisers - with the rest either in a security, support or a combined role.\n\nThe need to balance the force with more advisers is a driving factor behind the military's request for more troops, which has met with scepticism in Washington, where Trump was elected on a platform of reducing American commitments overseas.\n\nProviding security and support for the advising mission can be a deceptively dangerous job, with hours of quiet routine that can be broken by deadly violence at any moment.\n\nOn Aug. 2, two American soldiers were killed by a suicide car bomb as they were providing security for a convoy in the southern province of Kandahar.\n\nThe next day, a Georgian soldier was killed when a coalition convoy was attacked by a suicide bomber in Kabul.\n\nAnd just two days after that, Romanian soldiers providing security for advisers in Kandahar were forced to shoot and kill an Afghan policeman who attacked the international troops.\n\nFor the soldiers of the British army's Royal Irish Regiment in Kabul, this \"taxi and bodyguard service\" is a far cry from their last deployment to Afghanistan when they battled militants in Helmand province in 2011.\n\n\"We're there in the background if anything happens,\" said ranger Riley Tolliday, describing his job as a \"guardian angel\" escorting advisers to meetings around the Afghan capital.\n\nAfter months of relative calm, since April the Royal Irish Regiment has deployed a \"quick reaction force\" to at least three attacks in the city, said Major Paul Martin, a company commander.\n\nIn April, the regiment's soldiers were deployed to mediate a dispute that arose after a vehicle carrying foreign troops was involved in a traffic accident and was fired upon by Afghan police.\n\nIn early May, the soldiers escorted the disabled vehicles of an U.S. military convoy that had been struck by a suicide bomber, killing eight Afghan bystanders and wounding three Americans.\n\nAnd on May 31, they responded to the scene of a massive truck bomb that detonated in the center of Kabul, killing at least 92 people.\n\nThe British soldiers helped secure the scene and then evacuated casualties from the German embassy, which was heavily damaged.\n\nEven at the height of the international military mission in Afghanistan, a large proportion of troops was involved behind the scenes providing security and other support for the main mission.\n\nOf the 12,447 troops from 39 countries that make up the NATO-led Resolute Support mission, about 2,865 are classified as advisers, according to numbers provided by the coalition.\n\nAnother 7,766 are considered \"enablers\", which can range from logistics and security troops to fighter aircraft pilots.\n\nAnd, finally, 1,816 are deployed as \"command and control\".\n\nAmong the enablers plus command-and-control troops, many also have part-time roles advising Afghan counterparts, but the numbers reveal the massive number of supporting troops needed to field even a limited advising mission.\n\nAmong the 23,500 private contractors also employed by the U.S. military in Afghanistan, only 800 are classified as trainers, according to the Pentagon.\n\nErik Prince, the high-profile founder of the private security firm Blackwater, has proposed using contractors to take over all of the foreign mission in Afghanistan.\n\nWhile the U.S. military has used contractors to buttress the force in Afghanistan, including using private guards for security around some bases, officials say they hope to reduce overall reliance on contractors by deploying more troops.\n\nThe command in Kabul is now waiting on the stalled request for thousands more American troops, which they hope will allow them to deploy more soldiers dedicated to working with the Afghans, but also a \"significant\" number to provide more security, said one senior military official.\n\nSecurity services have seen a recent increase in demand as advisers try to reach more Afghan units, Martin said.\n\n\"We're able to fulfill about 80 percent of the requests we receive.\"\n\nThe troops tasked with escorting the advisers on their missions have to not only provide protection from potential militants, but also from so-called insider attacks by members of the Afghan security forces, who have occasionally turned on their foreign allies.", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100, "id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Fire and Security"}, Jarrod Morris/U.S. Army)\n\nAn American service member was killed Wednesday and an unspecific number wounded while battling Islamic State loyalists in eastern Afghanistan.\n\nMembers of the Afghan army also sustained casualties in what the U.S. military characterized as a partnered operation.\n\nOfficials in Kabul have said little else about the engagement, releasing only a brief statement indicating that the wounded were evacuated for medical treatment, the families of those involved were being notified, and the mission was said to be aimed at \"further reducing\" the Islamic State's regional presence.\n\nThe statement does not specify where the attack occurred, although ISIS militants are known to be active along the Pakistan border in Nangahar and Kunar provinces.\n\n[Blackwater's founder wants Trump to outsource the Afghanistan war. Why that's so risky.]\n\nWednesday's fatality is the 11th suffered by U.S. forces in Afghanistan this year, surpassing last year's total of 10. All but one resulted from hostile enemy action, according to Defense Department data. It comes, too, as the United States' longest war nears the start of its 17th year, and the Trump administration remains without a clear strategy.\n\nThe ISIS affiliate in Afghanistan, a group known as ISIS Khorasan, or ISIS-K, is entrenched along the country's mountainous border with Pakistan. Backed by U.S. troops and firepower, Afghan commando units have aggressively pursued its fighters for many months and shown some progress in disrupting their activity.\n\n[McCain releases strategy for Afghanistan, preempting and rebuking Trump]\n\nAmerican and Afghan troops launched Operation Hamza in early March. The following month, U.S. forces carried out a massive airstrike on an ISIS tunnel complex in Nangarhar's Achin district, reportedly killing upward of 100 militants. At the time, U.S. officials estimated that between 400 and 700 ISIS-K militants remained in Afghanistan.\n\nISIS-K is an offshoot of the terrorist group's core network in Iraq and Syria, receiving tactical guidance and financial support from outside Afghanistan but few additional fighters.\n\nAbout 14,000 U.S. and NATO troops remain in Afghanistan. With backing from the Pentagon, the war's top commander, Army Gen. John Nicholson, wants to expand his force by about 4,000 American troops, with a match from other NATO countries.\n\nThe White House has not committed to that plan. Some advisers have suggested that contractors could gradually assume the training and advisory mission there, allowing U.S. troops to come home.\n\nRead more:\n\nIn bid to beat back the Taliban, Afghanistan, Taleban tells Trump , Middle East News & Top Stories - The Straits Times", "uri": "709779200", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T13:15:00Z", "time": "13:15:00", "body": "KABUL (Reuters) - The United States should withdraw all its troops from Afghanistan and stop listening to \"stooges\"in Kabul, the Taleban said in an open letter to United States President Donald Trump on Tuesday.\n\nThe Trump administration is working to finalise a regional strategy that could include nearly 4,000 additional US troops, part of a Nato-led coalition, that have been requested by commanders in the country.\n\nThat plan has faced scepticism in the White House, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention and foreign aid.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" the Taleban said in the English-language letter released to media and addressed to Trump.\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nThe Taleban, seeking to restore Islamic rule, have been waging an increasingly violent insurgency against the Western-backed Afghan government since losing power in a US-led military operation in 2001.\n\nIn the lengthy statement, the Taleban criticised the Afghan government as \"stooges\", \"lying corrupt leaders\" and \"repulsive sellouts\" who are providing Washington with overly optimistic\"rosy pictures\" of the situation in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The war situation in Afghanistan is far worse than you realize!\" the statement said, while arguing that the only thing preventing the insurgents from seizing major cities was a fear of causing civilian casualties.\n\nThe statement also took aim at generals, whom the Taleban said \"are concealing the real statistics of your dead and crippled\" soldiers.\n\n\"We have noticed that you have understood the errors of your predecessors and have resolved to thoroughly rethink your new strategy in Afghanistan,\" the letter said. \"A number of warmongering congressmen and generals in Afghanistan are pressing you to protract the war in Afghanistan because they seek to preserve their military privileges.\"\n\nThe senior US commander in Afghanistan, General John Nicholson, has requested several thousand additional troops to act as advisers to the struggling Afghan security forces.\n\nPowerful voices in the US government, including Republican Senator John McCain, have also called for an \"enduring\" US military presence in Afghanistan.\n\nThe Taleban letter concludes by saying the conflict could be resolved by the withdrawal of foreign troops.\n\n\"Everyone now understands that the main driver of war in Afghanistan is foreign occupation,\" the Taleban said. \"The Afghans have no ill-intention towards the Americans or any other nation around the world but if anyone violates their sanctums then they are mighty proficient at beating and defeating the transgressors.\"", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", {"sim": 0.5921568870544434, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9423177", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "reuters.com", "title": "Reuters", "id": "8"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://yospace-cds1.reuters.com/u/resize~ad1~1200/0/f/~image_jpeg~9999-1/1/m/r/3/6/i/2lcw/reuters04?videoId=131631257", "extractedDates": null, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/video/2017/08/16/afghan-taliban-warns-trump-against-sendi?videoId=372328520&videoChannel=2602", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "07:23:00", "title": "Afghan Taliban warns Trump against sending in more troops", "uri": "710165712", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T07:23:00Z", "time": "07:23:00", "body": "The Taliban tells Donald Trump in an open letter that sending in more troops to Afghanistan would be self-destructive, as the U.S. president weighs up extra boots on the ground. Samantha Vadas reports.\n\nA stern warning for Donald Trump as he considers America's next move in Afghanistan. The Afghan Taliban penning a lengthy open letter to the U.S. president saying the situation on the ground is quote \"far worse that you realise\" and sending in more troops would be self-destructive. The letter also slams the Afghan government, labelling officials \"stooges\" and \"lying corrupt leaders\" who are feeding Washington \"rosy pictures\" of the military position. It also says that the only thing preventing the Taliban from seizing major cities is a fear of causing civilian casualties. The unusual decision to address Trump comes as he weighs up the future of U.S. policy in Afghanistan. Several thousand additional troops have been requested by senior army officials. But suggestions of more boots on the ground have been met with scepticism in the white house, where Trump and several top aides have criticised years of American military intervention.", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "wgt": 100, "id": 164, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare and Conflict"}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Scouting/Organizations", "wgt": 100, "id": 258, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Scouting/Organizations"}], "concepts": [{"location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Afghanistan", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Islamic Republic of Afghanistan"}, "type": "loc", "id": "2"}, {"location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States"}, "type": "loc", "id": "233"}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "id": "302942", "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taliban", "type": "org", "score": 4, "id": "303355", "label": {"eng": "Taliban"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/President_of_the_United_States", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "id": "304262", "label": {"eng": "President of the United States"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_letter", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "id": "310909", "label": {"eng": "Open letter"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_Afghanistan", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "id": "342305", "label": {"eng": "Politics of Afghanistan"}}]}
{"sim": 0.5882353186607361, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-16", "id": "9522580", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "algemeiner.com", "title": "Algemeiner.com", "id": "9526"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://www.algemeiner.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/03/Brits.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 163, "textEnd": 181, "date": "2001-09-11", "amb": false}], "url": "https://www.algemeiner.com/2017/08/16/time-is-ticking-for-trump-in-afghanistan/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "16:34:00", "title": "Time Is Ticking for Trump in Afghanistan", "uri": "710431464", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T16:34:00Z", "time": "16:34:00", "body": "As President Trump wrestles with America's role in Afghanistan, he should first decide what our objectives are today, compared to what we wanted immediately after September 11, 2001.\n\nInitially, the United States overthrew the Taliban regime; but we failed to destroy it completely. Regime supporters, allied tribal forces and opportunistic warlords escaped (or returned) to Pakistan's frontier regions to establish sanctuaries.\n\nSimilarly, while the Taliban's ouster also forced Al Qaeda into exile in Pakistan and elsewhere, the terror group nonetheless continued and expanded its terrorist activities. In Iraq and Syria, Al Qaeda morphed into the even more virulent ISIS, which is now gaining strength in Afghanistan.\n\nIn short, America's Afghan victories were significant, but incomplete. Subsequently, we failed to revise and update our Afghan strategic objectives, leading many to argue that the war had gone on too long and that we should withdraw. This criticism is superficially appealing, recalling anti-Vietnam War activist Allard Lowenstein's cutting remarks about Richard Nixon's policies. While Lowenstein acknowledged that he understood those, like Senator George Aiken, who said we should \"win and get out,\" Lowenstein said that he couldn't understand Nixon's strategy of \"lose and stay in.\"\n\nToday in Afghanistan, the pertinent question is what we seek to prevent, not what we seek to achieve. Making Afghanistan serene and peaceful does not constitute a legitimate American geopolitical interest. Instead, we face two principal threats.\n\nFirst, the Taliban's return to power throughout Afghanistan would re-create the prospect of the country being used as a base of operations for international terrorism. It is simply unacceptable to allow the pre-2001 status quo to re-emerge.\n\nSecond, a post-9/11 goal (at least one better understood today) is preventing a Taliban victory in Afghanistan that would enable the Pakistani Taliban or other terrorist groups to seize control in Islamabad. Not only would such a takeover make all of Pakistan yet another terrorist sanctuary, but if its large nuclear arsenal fell to terrorists, we would immediately face the equivalent of Iran and North Korea on nuclear steroids. Worryingly, Pakistan's military -- especially its intelligence arm -- is already thought to be controlled by radical Islamists.\n\nGiven terrorism's global spread since 9/11 and the risk of a perfect storm -- the confluence of terrorism and the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction -- the continuing threats we face in the Afghan arena are even graver than those posed before 9/11. Accordingly, abandoning the field in Afghanistan is simply not a tenable strategy.\n\nOn the other hand, accomplishing America's goals does not require remaking Afghanistan's government, economy or military in our image. Believing that only \"nation building\" in Afghanistan could ultimately guard against the terrorist threat was mistaken. For too long, it distracted Washington and materially contributed to the decline in American public support for a continuing military presence there, despite the manifest need for it.\n\nThere is no chance that the Trump administration will pursue \"nation building\" in Afghanistan, as the president has repeatedly made clear. Speaking as a Reagan administration alumnus of USAID, I concur. We should certainly continue bilateral economic assistance to Afghanistan, which, strategically applied, served America well in countless circumstances during the Cold War and thereafter. But we should not conflate it with the diaphanous prospect of nation building.\n\nNor should we assume that the military component in Afghanistan must be a repetition or expansion of the boots-on-the-ground approach that the US has followed since the initial assault on the Taliban. Other alternatives appear available and should be seriously considered, including possibly larger US military commitments of the right sort.\n\nEven more important, there must be far greater focus on Pakistan.\n\nPakistan -- a nuclear weapons state that has been politically unstable since British India's 1947 partition, and is increasingly under Chinese influence because of the hostility with India -- is a volatile and lethal mix ultimately more important than Afghanistan itself. Until and unless Pakistan becomes convinced that interfering in Afghanistan is too dangerous and too costly, no realistic US military scenario in Afghanistan can succeed.\n\nThe stakes are high on the subcontinent, not just because of the \"Af-Pak\" problems, but because Pakistan, India and China are all nuclear powers. The Trump administration should not be mesmerized only by US troop levels. It must concentrate urgently on the bigger strategic picture. The size and nature of America's military commitment in Afghanistan will more likely emerge from that analysis rather than the other way around. And time is growing short.\n\nJohn Bolton, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, was the US permanent representative to the United Nations and, previously, the undersecretary of state for arms control and international security.", "date": "2017-08-16", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100, "id": 161, "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism"}, {"uri": {"sim": 0.5882353186607361, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9248023", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "sputniknews.com", "title": "Sputnik", "id": "1676"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://cdn5.img.sputniknews.com/images/104740/49/1047404936.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "https://sputniknews.com/asia/201708151056470929-us-afghanistan-withdrawal/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:46:00", "title": "Why US Won't Leave Central Asia Any Time Soon and What It is Really After There", "uri": "709687317", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T09:46:00Z", "time": "09:46:00", "body": "Why isn't the US ready to withdraw from Afghanistan despite failing to reach any success during its 16-year-long military presence there? Sputnik Afghanistan discussed it with Afghan political analyst Akhtar Shakh Hamdard, who explained what the real purposes of the US presence in this country and the whole of Central Asia are.\n\n\u00a9 WikipediaUS' Blackwater Mercenaries 'Will Bring Hatred, Not Peace to Afghanistan'On Monday, Russian high-ranking career diplomat and Russian presidential envoy to Afghanistan Zamir Kabulov acknowledged the failure of the US military campaign in Afghanistan.\n\n\"The American campaign in Afghanistan has failed. Afghanistan risks becoming a global incubator of international terrorism. It has, in fact, already partially grown to become it,\" Kabulov said in an interview with Russia's Izvestiya newspaper.\n\nKabulov, who is also the Russian Foreign Ministry's director of the Second Asian Department in Afghanistan, therefore urged for withdrawal of the US troops from the country and said that Russia opposes the US idea to replace the regular US Army there with private military contractors.\n\n\"Moscow never hastened the withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan. But since the US Army [campaign] there has come to nothing, let them leave Afghanistan,\" he said.\n\nSputnik Afghanistan discussed the issue with Afghan political analyst Akhtar Shakh Hamdard, who explained why the US won't leave the country \"any time soon\" despite reaching no success there.\n\n\"The US has long-term strategic plans for Afghanistan. They have built their military bases there. Americans have made serious investments into the region, where their opponents (Russia and China) may cause a serious damage to Washington through Afghanistan,\" the political analyst told Sputnik.\n\n\u00a9 REUTERS/ Omar SobhaniWhat's Behind Russia's Warning of 'Resorting to Military Force' in Afghanistan?He also echoed another comment of Zamir Kabulov, where he referred to the recent calls of Erik D. Prince, most infamous US military contractor and a founder of the private military company Blackwater Worldwide, to restore the British East India Company approach, which in effect ruled parts of India in the 18th and 19th centuries.\n\n\"It pretty much resembles a colonial policy. Prince suggested restoring the British East India Company. The Americans therefore revealed their plans: Afghanistan is nothing more than a colony for them,\" Kabulov told Izvestiya.\n\n\"The US has announced Central Asia a zone of their interests, as it is rich of explored natural resources reserves. Iran, which is also rich of oil and gas, is also of strategic importance to Washington. And the shortest route from the US to Iran is through Afghanistan,\" Akhtar Shakh Hamdard told Sputnik.\n\nThese are the reasons why the US won't leave any time soon and all the speculations on this topic are nothing but a usual political game of the US, the political analyst elaborated. Besides, he said, the US has made an agreement with the government of Afghanistan, which made their military present in the country absolutely legal.\n\nThe US is spending on Afghanistan about $20-25 billion, it is mere trifle for the country with an annual military budget of $600 billion, he said. The only thing the US is concerned about is its personnel losses in the country, which could lead to protests within the US.\n\n\u00a9 Sputnik/ Alexandr GraschenkovMystery Aviation in Afghanistan: Whose is it?The political analyst also commented on whether the activity of Taliban and Daesh in Afghanistan might force the US to leave.\n\n\"Daesh is the project of the US, UK and Israel. Under their plan, Daesh was supposed to conquer Central Asia through Iran and Afghanistan and further threaten Russia. Daesh militants should have wiped off Shia regime in Iran, seizure the Caucasus and through Afghanistan - Central Asia,\" Akhtar Shakh Hamdard.\n\nThe successful Russia's campaign in Syria has foiled {"sim": 0.5843137502670288, "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3368636", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "id": "9805778", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "sify.com", "title": "Sify", "id": "186"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://static.sify.com/cms/commons/widget/images/featured-thumbs-default-img.gif", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 200, "textEnd": 206, "date": "2017-08-18", "amb": false}, {"imp": true, "textStart": 1680, "textEnd": 1686, "date": "2017-08-02", "amb": false}, {"textStart": 3101, "textEnd": 3107, "date": "-05-31", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.sify.com/news/guardian-angel-need-for-advisers-in-afghanistan-drives-call-for-more-troops-news-politics-risgXTaghhdie.html", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "01:38:00", "title": "\"Guardian angel\" need for advisers in Afghanistan drives call for more troops", "uri": "711199629", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T01:38:00Z", "time": "01:38:00", "body": "* International advisers in Afghanistan require huge troop backup\n\n* Most troops assigned to security, support roles\n\n* Trump and aides to discuss Afghan strategy, troop levels\n\nBy Josh Smith\n\nKABUL, Aug 18 (Reuters) - Navigating a chaotic maze of cars and people, the convoy of British army armoured vehicles weaves slowly through Kabul. The job of about a dozen soldiers is to protect just two international advisers on their way to meet Afghan soldiers.\n\nWhile every mission varies, for every adviser deployed in Afghanistan as part of a NATO-led multinational force, many more soldiers are tasked with providing security and support.\n\nThe minimum security requirements mean that providing even just a few thousand advisers for Afghan security forces is a monumental task that, if continued, will keep many thousands more international troops and contractors facing daily threats.\n\nThat calculus will factor into arguments put before U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday as he and advisers meet ahead of a long-awaited decision on strategy and troop levels for the United States' longest war.\n\nFewer than 25 percent of coalition troops in Afghanistan are dedicated advisers - with the rest either in a security, support or a combined role.\n\nThe need to balance the force with more advisers is a driving factor behind the military's request for more troops, which has met with scepticism in Washington, where Trump was elected on a platform of reducing American commitments overseas.\n\nDANGEROUS JOB\n\nProviding security and support for the advising mission can be a deceptively dangerous job, with hours of quiet routine that can be broken by deadly violence at any moment.\n\nOn Aug. 2, two American soldiers were killed by a suicide car bomb as they were providing security for a convoy in the southern province of Kandahar.\n\nThe next day, a Georgian soldier was killed when a coalition convoy was attacked by a suicide bomber in Kabul.\n\nAnd just two days after that, Romanian soldiers providing security for advisers in Kandahar were forced to shoot and kill an Afghan policeman who attacked the international troops.\n\nFor the soldiers of the British army's Royal Irish Regiment in Kabul, this \"taxi and bodyguard service\" is a far cry from their last deployment to Afghanistan when they battled militants in Helmand province in 2011.\n\n\"We're there in the background if anything happens,\" said ranger Riley Tolliday, describing his job as a \"guardian angel\" escorting advisers to meetings around the Afghan capital.\n\nAfter months of relative calm, since April the Royal Irish Regiment has deployed a \"quick reaction force\" to at least three attacks in the city, said Major Paul Martin, a company commander.\n\nIn April, the regiment's soldiers were deployed to mediate a dispute that arose after a vehicle carrying foreign troops was involved in a traffic accident and was fired upon by Afghan police.\n\nIn early May, the soldiers escorted the disabled vehicles of an U.S. military convoy that had been struck by a suicide bomber, killing eight Afghan bystanders and wounding three Americans.\n\nAnd on May 31, they responded to the scene of a massive truck bomb that detonated in the centre of Kabul, killing at least 92 people.\n\nThe British soldiers helped secure the scene and then evacuated casualties from the German embassy, which was heavily damaged.\n\nMORE ADVISERS NEED MORE PROTECTION\n\nEven at the height of the international military mission in Afghanistan, a large proportion of troops was involved behind the scenes providing security and other support for the main mission.\n\nOf the 12,447 troops from 39 countries that make up the NATO-led Resolute Support mission, about 2,865 are classified as advisers, according to numbers provided by the coalition.\n\nAnother 7,766 are considered \"enablers\", which can range from logistics and security troops to fighter aircraft pilots.\n\nAnd, finally, 1,816 are deployed as \"command and control\".\n\nAmong the enablers plus command-and-control troops, many also have part-time roles advising Afghan counterparts, but the numbers reveal the massive number of supporting troops needed to field even a limited advising mission.\n\nAmong the 23,500 private contractors also employed by the U.S. military in Afghanistan, only 800 are classified as trainers, according to the Pentagon.\n\nErik Prince, the high-profile founder of the private security firm Blackwater, has proposed using contractors to take over all of the foreign mission in Afghanistan.\n\nWhile the U.S. military has used contractors to buttress the force in Afghanistan, including using private guards for security around some bases, officials say they hope to reduce overall reliance on contractors by deploying more troops.\n\nThe command in Kabul is now waiting on the stalled request for thousands more American troops, which they hope will allow them to deploy more soldiers dedicated to working with the Afghans, but also a \"significant\" number to provide more security, said one senior military official.\n\nSecurity services have seen a recent increase in demand as advisers try to reach more Afghan units, Martin said.\n\n\"We're able to fulfil about 80 percent of the requests we receive.\" The troops tasked with escorting the advisers on their missions have to not only provide protection from potential militants, but also from so-called insider attacks by members of the Afghan security forces, who have occasionally turned on their foreign allies. (Editing by Nick Macfie)\n\nSEARCH", "date": "2017-08-18", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Fire_and_Security", "wgt": 100, "id": 107, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business {"sim": 0.5764706134796143, "details": {"gpCnt": 3}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9331994", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "thinkprogress.org", "title": "ThinkProgress", "id": "2430"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "https://thinkprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/ap_17105430285206.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "url": "https://thinkprogress.org/taliban-tells-us-get-out-of-afghanistan-48fcce1bba17/", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:56:00", "title": "The Taliban invites the U.S. to get out of Afghanistan", "uri": "709905080", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T17:56:00Z", "time": "17:56:00", "body": "There has been talk of a decision for months, but so far, the Trump administration still doesn't have a plan.\n\nAs the Trump administration tries to figure out what to do next in Afghanistan, the Taliban makes its wishes clear: It wants the United States out.\n\nThat the Taliban would want U.S. forces out is a given. What's surprising is that its wish might come true: Defense Secretary James Mattis on Monday told reporters that \"all options\" - including the use of military contractors and full troop withdrawal - were on the table, but that \"the strategic decisions have not been made.\"\n\nOn Tuesday, Reuters reported that the Taliban issued a statement addressing President Donald Trump, saying that the \"situation in Afghanistan is far worse\" than he realizes and that he should stop listening to \"lying corrupt\" Afghan leaders and \"stooges.\"\n\nThe Taliban, which currently holds more territory in the central Asian country than at any time since the U.S. invasion in 2001, made its preference clear: U.S. troops should leave.\n\n\"Previous experiences have shown that sending more troops to Afghanistan will not result in anything other than further destruction of American military and economical might,\" read the statement.\n\nThe most decisive thing the President Donald Trump has done so far in Afghanistan is to drop the \"mother of all bombs\" (MOAB) on a complex of caves in Achin in April.\n\nThe bomb (a 21,600-pound device - the largest non-nuclear one used in combat) was meant to decimate an ISIS enclave in the area. There were unconfirmed reports of roughly 100 ISIS fighters being killed, but even if true, the powerful blast has failed to stop ISIS in its tracks.\n\nThe Taliban, meanwhile, continue their daily attacks around the country, targeting civilians and security forces alike.\n\nAdam Stump, a pentagon spokesman, declined to comment on the Taliban statement and said there is no timeline for neither when the \"multiple options\" will be presented to the president, nor a deadline by which the president is to decide the course of action.\n\n\"There's a full range of options - we don't discuss what the specific options are,\" said Stump, who also declined to say how many options were being considered.\n\nAside from troop withdrawal, one option could see the United States sending roughly 4,000 troops to Afghanistan to bolster the 8,500 there. Another could include hiring thousands of military contractors - although the use of such contractors has resulted in civilian deaths and backlash in the past.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": {"sim": 0.5764706134796143, "details": {"liCnt": 51}, "storyUri": "eng-3362637", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "id": "9310279", "lang": "eng", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "title": "Newsweek", "id": "14218"}, "location": null, "eventUri": "eng-3362637", "image": "http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/full/public/2017/08/15/rts19v1q.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textStart": 1938, "textEnd": 1945, "date": "2017-07-31", "amb": false}], "url": "http://www.newsweek.com/down-its-luck-syria-and-iraq-isis-outsources-terror-attacks-pakistani-taliban-650926", "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "15:49:00", "title": "ISIS is \"outsourcing\" its attacks to the Pakistani Taliban in Afghanistan, U.N. report says", "uri": "709847498", "isDuplicate": false, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T15:49:00Z", "time": "15:49:00", "body": "After losing territory and power in Syria and Iraq, the Islamic State Militant group (ISIS) is outsourcing its deadly attacks on the U.S.-backed government in Afghanistan to local splinter groups including the Pakistani Taliban, because it lacks manpower.\n\nClaiming responsibility for a string of high profile attacks in the country in recent months, particularly in Kabul, ISIS is vying with the more established Taliban and Al-Qaeda in the Indian Subcontinent (AQIS) for dominance in Afghanistan.\n\nHowever, a recent U.N. report has said while the leadership of the groups remain in open competition for the hearts and minds of Afghanistan's Islamists, ISIS tends to enlist \"partners of convenience\" and \"outsources\" attacks to other local splinter groups including the Tehrik-e Taliban Pakistan, an umbrella group for branches of the Pakistani Taliban.\n\nDaily Emails and Alerts - Get the best of Newsweek delivered to your inbox\n\nRead More: Afghanistan: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Bomb Attack on Iraqi Embassy in Kabul\n\nThe need to reach out to these groups stems from the militants' lack of presence on the ground. ISIS's core leadership continues to send funds to Afghanistan despite its depleted resources in its heartlands in Iraq and Syria but the U.N. report states that ISIS in Afghanistan would simply cease to exist without this support.\n\nThe militant group has instructed its affiliate in Afghanistan to push towards the north of of the country but despite its recruitment efforts over the past three years, the militants have not yet established a viable fighting force there.\n\nAt the end of July, ISIS claimed responsibility for an attack on the Iraqi Embassy in the Afghan capital Kabul that began with a suicide bomber blowing himself up at the main gate, allowing gunmen to enter the building and battle security forces.\n\nAfghan security forces leave the site of an attack on the Iraqi embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan, July 31. REUTERS/Mohammad Ismail\n\nISIS has carried out attacks in the Afghan capital targeting members of the mainly Shiite Hazara community. The violence has fueled concerns of a possible spillover into Afghanistan of sectarian violence of the kind seen in Syria and Iraq, Reuters reported.\n\nThe alliances between different groups remain in flux. At the beginning of this month, Afghan officials said Afghan Taliban fighters, separate to the Pakistani Taliban and usually oppsed to ISIS, joined forces with Sher Mohammed Ghazanfar, a commander who has pledged allegiance to the militant group, massacring dozens of civilians in a village.\n\nAQIS and the Taliban are far stronger in terms of internal funding sources and recruits. The two groups are increasingly working alongside each other, causing havoc for the U.S-backed coalition that is trying to degrade them.\n\nThe U.N. estimates there may be as many as 7,000 AQIS and Taliban fighters in Afghanistan. As the Taliban continues to wield substantial influence over AQIS, many Al-Qaeda-affiliated fighters from the Afghanistan-Pakistan border area have integrated into the Taliban, increasing its military capability.\n\nAlso in July, 35 people were killed in a Taliban attack on government workers in Kabul, underlining Afghanistan's precarious security situation as the United States considers an overhaul of its policy in the region.\n\nWhite House concerns about levels of troops in Afghanistan have reportedly led the Trump administration to a point where it is considering withdrawing U.S. troops from the beleaguered country altogether, against recommendations from the Pentagon.\n\nWithout a clear strategy set out by defense officials, a schism has opened in the administration over U.S. involvement in the country. At the end of April the U.S. military said it would deploy 1,500 soldiers to Afghanistan in response to ISIS and Taliban attacks. However, without broad agreement, it looks unlikely the U.S. will send out forces this summer.", "date": "2017-08-15", "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100, "id": 161,
